headline: Sir Alex Ferguson's former right-hand man pulls no punches with Cristiano Ronaldo verdict
body: Former Manchester United first-team coach Rene Meulensteen has given his verdict on if Cristiano Ronaldo should start for Portugal against France on Friday in the Euro 2024 quarter-finals
Sir Alex Ferguson's former right-hand man, Rene Meulensteen, has given his stark opinion on Cristiano Ronaldo's Euro 2024 performances for Portugal.

His verdict was revealed on talkSPORT's YouTube channel as Jim White and Alex Crook interviewed the former Manchester United first-team coach. Meulensteen has claimed that Portugal manager Roberto Martinez has got to address Ronaldo's lack of free-kick goals for his country at Euro 2024 as he noted that the game is beginning to "run away" from the elite athlete.

TalkSPORT co-host Alex Crooks asked Meulensteen: "Are they a better team without him in it, Portugal? He takes every free kick, blazes every free kick into the stands." And the former assistant to Sir Alex said: "Yeah well, that to me is something I think that needs to be addressed because the stats don't help."

Meulensteen also discussed the Portugal frontman's emotional state during and after the round of 16 game against Slovenia - where he burst into tears after seeing his penalty saved by Jan Oblak, but then went on to score one in the shoot-out after extra time.

The former United coach said: "Well, it's all about perception isn't it? First of all, I thought when that penalty shoot-out came about, I thought this is going to be interesting because he's only going to take one or another penalty – he's either the first one or number five, the last one.

"And I was pleasantly surprised for him to step up and take the first one because he knew, 'I need to take the responsibility, I need to put this right to get us off of the wrong foot'. So that to me was a good sign of character."

Meulensteen added: "What happened after the game showed his determination and his desire to win things and to do well that is so strong. He's got the highest expectations of himself and everybody around him. He expects the highest standards of himself and everybody else, and if he doesn't meet those standards - which he didn't - then obviously you get that reaction from him."

Meulensteen also noted that Ronaldo needs to justify his claim of taking free-kicks for Portugal by boosting his conversion rate. He explained: "The only way to justify it [taking free kicks] is to put one in the top corner and that is obviously what he's got in his mind but the stats don't back that up and the thing is, you know with every team normally, you've got a clear plan with everything in terms of the corners, who takes them and the free kicks and this and that and the other.
"He sees them [free kicks] as an opportunity but it's not working and I think it's the manager's job to address that."

Jim White, the former Sky Sports Transfer Deadline Day presenter, asked Meulensteen if he would put Ronaldo in the starting XI for Portugal's game against France on Friday night. White posed the question: "If you were Martinez, I'm going to do it, I'm going to put you in that spot, would you play him in this game against the French on Friday, would you start him?"
Meulensteen replied: "Yeah, I would start him, yeah I would." White then asked: "Would you say anything specific to him before he went out?"

The former United coach, who is now an assistant coach for the Australian national team, said: "I would probably have a clear conversation with him then with the leadership group and also in the tactical way that we, if we think we're going to beat France then I expect something different from you, from you, from you and from you.
"And the only way we can do that is if we pull together and let everybody play to their strength, so therefore this is how we're going to do it."

headline: 5 transfers Man Utd can complete this summer as Erik ten Hag targets new centre-back
body: Erik ten Hag is here to stay at Man United and will be looking to improve his squad this summer transfer window following an FA Cup winning season at Old Trafford
Manchester United are set to bring in new recruits this transfer window on the back of extending manager Erik ten Hag's stay at Old Trafford.
While departures are set to be plentiful at United this summer, the arrivals lounge may also be busy as the new hierarchy looks to continue building the club for success.
A bid for Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite has already been rejected, while French pair Anthony Martial and Raphael Varane have left the club after their contracts expired.
But business is far from finished, with another centre-back tipped to arrive, Branthwaite to be further pursued, and a new name odds-on to join the Red Devils' forward line.
After playing perhaps the best football of his career under Ten Hag at Ajax, De Ligt has fallen out of favour at his current club Bayern Munich and a switch to Old Trafford has been mooted.
A £68million signing from Juventus, De Ligt hasn't lived up the expectations that surrounded him following Ajax's run to the Champions League semi-final in 2019.
Scoring in both the quarter-final against eventual club Juventus, and semi-final, where Ajax infamously fell to Tottenham, De Ligt was one of the hottest centre-back prospects on the market.
Failing to settle in Italy meant that the Bayern move could act as a reprieve, but the Dutchman now finds himself behind former Tottenham and England man Eric Dier in the pecking order.

United's centre-back roster is far from what they'd like it to be at the minute with Varane having departed and both Victor Lindelof and Harry Maguire likely to leave, so it is essential that an elite-level defender arrive to partner Lisandro Martinez.
Reports suggest De Ligt would cost the Red Devils £40million, a far cry from the near-£70million that Everton requested for Branthwaite.
Bayern's interest in Germany and Leverkusen centre-half Johnathan Tah all but confirms that De Ligt will head for the exit, and United are the most likely suitors.
With the aging Casemiro creeping towards a potential departure, a holding midfielder is another vacancy that United's new regime are keen to fill.
The name that is being heavily linked with a move to United is Uruguayan commander Manuel Ugarte, who currently plays for French champions PSG.
Lighting up this year's Copa America, Ugarte has played almost every minute of Uruguay's so-far impeccable campaign, attracting interest from Premier League clubs.
Having only left Sporting CP last summer to join Les Parisiens for around £50million, Ugarte fell out of favour with manager Luis Enrique.
A catalyst for the Uruguayan being dropped from the strarting XI was his lacklustre performance against Newcastle in the Champions league - where he was substituted after just 64 minutes.

Chelsea were incredibly close to bringing Ugarte to England last summer, and a deal was agreed, but PSG reportedly offered a better wage packet and the Blues ended up with Brighton's Moises Caicedo instead.

Now, the holding midfielder looks to potentially be on his way to England again in a move that could see him swap clubs for as little as £35million - £15million less than was paid for services just a year prior.
Ugarte could provide the stability in midfield that United have been craving, but any deal would most likely have to wait until his Copa America is over.
Dutch forward Zirkzee was a standout for Bologna in Serie A last season as they unexpectedly secured Champions League football under Thiago Motta.
Having left Feyenoord's academy for Bayern Munich's, Zirkzee rose through the ranks after scoring a hat-trick for the Bavarian club's reserves on his debut.
He made his first team debut against Tottenham in the Champions League in 2019 group stage, and was loaned out to Parma in January 2021.
Injuries scuppered his first loan move, but his second the following season saw him head to Anderlecht in Belgium where he became the club's top scorer with 15 league goals - 18 in all competitions.
Zirkzee was unable to assert any claim on Bayern's squad despite the goals, and was shipped out to Bologna in 2022 for as just £7.2million.
He was top scorer for his club again last season, and United now look set to recruit the Dutchman whose contract reportedly has a £34million release clause.
Bologna will be upset to lose their star forward for such a relatively small fee, but United will be glad to hopefully add his goals to a forward line that stuttered at times last season.
With players like Jadon Sancho and Antony linked with moves away, and Martial having already left, a new forward is essential and Zirkzee fits the bill.
A transfer that may turn out to be one of the sagas of the summer, young centre-back Branthwaite has been linked with United for some time now.

Arriving at current club Everton from Carlisle United in 2020, the defender has enjoyed loan spells at Blackburn and PSV Eindhoven before returning to become part of the first-team last season under Sean Dyche.

Branthwaite was nothing short of a revelation for the Toffees, combining his powerful defending with the netting of some crucial goals against Tottenham and Liverpool as they avoided the drop for the second year running.
His performances at Goodsion Park lead to him being called up to Gareth Southgate's provisional England squad for Euro 2024, and saw him earn his first international cap against Bosnia at Wembley.
With centre-half a desperate need for Man United, Branthwaite made sense, but the valuations that both United and Everton held were vastly different.
An opening bid of just £35million plus add-ons was far below the reported £70million valuation that Everton have placed on the defender, and so the deal has stalled.
With the De Ligt transfer looking like the preferred option, the potential for both defenders to arrive at United still remains a possibility considering the departures that United will sanction.
If Lindelof and Maguire were to leave, this would open up positions within the squad, so there is no writing off the idea that United will sign two premier centre-backs this summer.
A lesser known name but another possible arrival, Spanish left-back Gutierrez could be poised to fill a position that United have been desperate for consistency in for some time.
Currently at Spanish side Girona, where he arrived in 2022, the defender aided his side in reaching the Champions League for the first time in their history last season.
His performances drew interest from a range of clubs and it is reported that Liverpool and Arsenal were both interested in the player before he seemingly chose United.

It may not be Girona whose pocket the reported £34million fee will fill if this transfer goes ahead, however, as Gutierrez joined from champions Real Madrid who have a minimal buy-back clause on the defender.
The plan would be that Los Blancos purchase the player back from Girona only to sell him on to the Red Devils.

This isn't the first time that the player has been linked to United either, as in 2017 former United coach Jose Mourinho was keen on bringing in the defender who eventually decided on remaining in Madrid.
Both Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia haven't been able to string a consistent spell of games together in the position that Gutierrez would fill.

headline: Huge Man Utd controversy caused real problem for Gary Lineker on Match of the Day
body: Eric Cantona's vicious kick at an abusive Crystal Palace fan had direct consequences for Gary Lineker, who was appearing on Match of the Day as a pundit back in 1995
Eric Cantona’s infamous Manchester United kung-fu kick caused Gary Lineker a huge problem on one of his first ever Match of the Day appearances.

Imagery of Cantona launching himself at a Crystal Palace fan in the Selhurst Park stands is ingrained in the minds of every English football fan. The maverick Frenchman had been sent off for a wild tackle during the fixture on January 25, 1995, but saw red again after being told to go “back to France”, along with some more colourful language, by a Palace supporter.

The rest is history, with Cantona’s assault resulting in him receiving a £20,000 fine, two weeks in jail and a nine-month ban from playing football. And it had repercussions for a nervous and fresh-faced Lineker, who was stumped when asked for his thoughts on the incident on the BBC’s flagship sports programme - which he has since presented for 25 years.

Lineker revealed his difficult position at the time while speaking to Cantona on The Rest Is Football podcast. “That was one of my first ever appearances on Match of the Day as a pundit,” the 63-year-old anchor said.
“He’s gone to me ‘so what did you make of that?’ and I thought ‘Oh my God, I never expected to have to deal with this, thank you very much, Eric’,” resulting in a chuckle from Cantona.

The former Red Devils man had been asked if he had any regrets regarding his career by Alan Shearer, whose Blackburn Rovers side beat United to the Premier League title that season. Cantona jokingly responded: “I have one regret, if it didn’t happen you wouldn't have won the Premier League – it was when I was banned in 1995.”

Explaining his moment of incredible head loss, he added: “Sometimes we are fragile. In football, it’s all about provocation from the fans. The fans can use any type of thing to help their team to win.

“But sometimes it’s difficult to say that because we cannot accept racist chants from the stands, because he said something about me being French. I heard that thousands of times before, that’s football.”
Shearer then chimed in by saying: “I can only say thank you because we might not have won the league if you haven’t done it so I was your biggest f***ing fan when you did that!”

Blackburn went on to win the league, a feat they have not managed since, by a single point. Cantona’s absence proved a huge blow for runners-up United, having scored 12 league goals and notched five assists until he was suspended for the remainder of the season.

headline: Bruno Fernandes showed his true colours when quizzed on Cristiano Ronaldo spat
body: They have been team-mates at Manchester United and for Portugal, but some people have thought that Cristiano Ronaldo and Bruno Fernandes would clash
When the going has got tough, Bruno Fernandes has always launched a staunch defence of Cristiano Ronaldo.

Fans were left frustrated on Fernandes' behalf this pas week during Portugal's narrow win over Slovenia in the Euro 2024 Round of 16. This stemmed from Ronaldo taking four free-kicks in dangerous positions - and not coming close to scoring any of them.

Ronaldo then missed a spot-kick in extra-time, which would've prevented the match from going to a penalty shootout. Ronaldo's insistence of taking all the set pieces only added to many supporters' feeling that the pair, who have played together at Manchester United as well as at international level, do not see eye-to-eye.

The seeds of this rumour were planted when Fernandes looked to have given Ronaldo the cold shoulder in the Portugal changing room, soon after the 39-year-old chastised United in an explosive interview with Piers Morgan.

When the video first emerged without sound, a Sky Sports journalist said it looked like the pair were exchanging jibes at each other. Fernandes quickly replied: “They put the sound on after, did you hear it with the sound?

"You have to hear it. In Portugal, we have a problem that I was watching on one of the channels that was talking about that. [They were saying] ‘It was cold, it was bad’ for about 45 minutes. All of a sudden, they go for a break and the national team put it up with the sound and the sound says that he’s joking with me.

“They came back and said there was a joke, and they cut there. They they said ‘If you want to see again, just go back’, but if they go back, they will see that was a problem. But if they tell the truth, if they explain what was in that video, people will know, but now people don’t know.

“As I said, this is national team, Manchester United will be my focus after the World Cup. I have no problem with anyone. One time a manager said to be ‘Everything that you can control is yourself’. I think everyone thinks the same way."

Ronaldo and Fernandes appeared to have developed a friendly understanding during Portugal's 3-0 victory over Turkey. The five-time Ballon d'Or was played through on goal, but instead of shooting, he cut the ball across to Fernandes for a tap-in.

While Fernandes would have appreciated Ronaldo's pass then, he, as would all of the Portugal players, would've been extremely frustrated by the iconic forward's insistence of taking every free-kick within range of the goal. Ronaldo did not come close to scoring from any of his dead ball situations, which were more often than not more than 30 yards away from goal.

He is yet to score a single goal across the whole competition and has not found the net for the national side since he scored two goals in a friendly against Ireland last month. Ronaldo will almost certainly start in Portugal's quarter-final clash against France.

Considering how strong France are, Portugal will need to make any and every opportunity they get to score count. Considering Ronaldo's recent struggles with his set pieces, legendary England forward Gary Lineker thinks Fernandes is the better taker. “It is almost impossible, despite the fact his record is something like one in 60 that he’s scored in tournaments," Lineker said on the Rest is Football podcast
“Bruno Fernandes is a better free-kick taker and a more varied free-kick taker than Ronaldo. So while he’s [Ronaldo] a massive strength, he can also be a weakness as well."

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Marcus Rashford warning sent as flop edges towards exit
body: Manchester United are expected to undergo a major overhaul over this summer's transfer window, with Marcus Rashford one of the players linked with an exit from Old Trafford
With Erik ten Hag's new contract now signed, sealed and delivered, Manchester United can start to focus on recruitment.

The Dutchman has signed a new two-year deal, cementing his position as Red Devils manager. Work will now begin to boost his squad after a disappointing season, with attack and defence seen as a priority.
To fund those moves though, a number of players appear to be set for a departure. Donny van de Beek is an obvious candidate to leave, though Marcus Rashford has also been linked with an exit.

United have now been cautioned against allowing the Englishman to depart though, as they turn their attention to PSG star Manuel Ugarte. Here, Mirror Football rounds up all the latest Manchester United transfer news.

Former Manchester United star Mikael Silvestre has warned the Red Devils they would be making a mistake if Marcus Rashford was sold. Rashford has been linked with an exit after a difficult season, but Silvestre believes he still has a part to play.

"Letting Rashford go would not be the right decision because you need to go in the market and find someone better than Marcus, if that's the case. If you find that player he will be very expensive," he said.
"Marcus is a senior, experienced Mancunian from the academy. I think he wants to stay. The manager likes him. I just hope Marcus bounces back this season.”

United have stepped up their pursuit of PSG star Manuel Ugarte with Bayern Munich now out of the race. Ugarte only joined PSG last summer from Sporting Lisbon but fell down the pecking order towards the end of the season.

That has put him in line for a departure from the Parc des Princes, with United's interest gathering pace. According to reports from France, Bayern's move for Joao Palhinha has cleared the way for the Red Devils.

Ugarte had been a potential target for the German giants, but signing Palhinha has put any deal for the Uruguyan on the backburner. That has opened the door for United, who now consider him to be an 'important target'.

Flop Donny van de Beek is closing in on a departure from Manchester United after a miserable four-year spell at the club. Van de Beek was sent out on loan to Eintracht Frankfurt in January, but started just four games.

They opted against activating an option to buy him for £9.5m, with the Dutchman set to return to United for pre-season training next week. According to the Manchester Evening News, it clould be a short comeback, with club chiefs working on a permanent exit.

A permanent move is said to be the target for 'all parties' this summer, with Van de Beek's contract having just one year to run. Another loan move has been ruled out, with United keen to recoup at least some of the fee they shelled out on the midfielder.

headline: Sergio Reguilon made Man Utd feelings clear with Old Trafford return on the cards
body: Tottenham Hotspur defender Sergio Reguilon is set to leave the club this summer and Manchester United have been named as a possible destination as he enters the final year of his contract
Sergio Reguilon is expected to leave Tottenham Hotspur this summer, and it appears Manchester United are a candidate to bring the defender back to Old Trafford.

Spurs full back Reguilon spent the first half of last season on loan at Old Trafford, having initially expected to have a place under new boss Ange Postecoglou. The Spaniard had an inconsistent time working under Erik ten Hag, as he came in and out of the team before United ended his time with the club prematurely in the January transfer window.

The 27-year-old made 12 appearances for the Red Devils during his short spell, but reports in Spain suggest the club could yet be a surprise destination for the former Sevilla star. Reguilon, who arrived at Tottenham in a £28million deal in 2020, had more joy on loan at Brentford last term where he made 16 appearances and provided four assists.

West Ham and Juventus are listed among the other candidates for Reguilon's signature. Julen Lopetegui is set to enter his first season in charge of the Irons and presided over Reguilon's most successful season in 2019/20 with Sevilla.

Despite a truncated time at Old Trafford, Reguilon appears to bear no ill will towards Man United. The Real Madrid youth product delivered a positive parting message when he departed at the beginning of 2024.

"It has been great to play for Manchester United and I just want to say thank you to the club, the fans and my teammates," he said. "It was a privilege to play for this huge club. I wish all the best for the Red Devils."

After joining the club to start 2023/24, Reguilon was enthusiastic about the opportunity to work with Ten Hag. In a club interview Reguilon said of the Dutchman: "He wanted me to come and I wanted to come here too. It was all very easy.

"Now I am here and we have been speaking in training about what he wants from his left-back. I think we share the same philosophy. He likes hard workers and I love working hard, I think we're on exactly the same page."

While United have been linked with a move to Reguilon, their priorities remain in other positions. The club are planning to land a centre-back, midfielder and striker in the coming weeks despite their budget starting at £50m before player sales.

headline: Erik ten Hag gets his wish after making demand during Man Utd contract talks
body: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag has had his contract extended until 2026 - and the Dutchman is set to retain the transfer veto that he wanted to remain in place
Erik ten Hag will retain his transfer veto after having his contract extended by Manchester United's top brass.

There had been speculation that the Dutchman, 54, would lose his job this summer after overseeing one of the club's worst campaigns in decades, although he did end the season with a flourish by beating Manchester City in the FA Cup final.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe is now calling the shots at Old Trafford and he and his football operations teams have been in talks with Ten Hag over a new contract after deciding to persevere with the former Ajax chief, with an agreement being formally announced on Thursday.

As outlined in a report by The Times, Ten Hag will retain the right to veto transfers - an agreement which featured in the original contract he signed back in the summer of 2022 when he joined United.

Mirror Football have previously outlined that Ten Hag had made it clear during talks with the club hierarchy that he was not prepared to relinquish control over identifying potential transfer targets and the team's style of play.
United have had a chequered record in the transfer market in recent years and Ten Hag's biggest signing, Antony, has failed to live up to expectations since joining from Ajax for a fee of

But it seems Ten Hag has got his wish after United opted to trigger the one-year option in his contract - which takes him up to the summer of 2026 - rather than hand him a new contract, meaning his transfer veto remains in place.

The club's new sporting director, Dan Ashworth, said of the news: “With two trophies in the past two seasons, Erik has reinforced his record as one of the most consistently successful coaches in European football.

“While the club’s review of last season highlighted areas for improvement, it also reached a clear conclusion that Erik was the best partner for us to work with in driving up standards and outcomes. This group of players and staff have already shown they are capable of competing and winning at the top level; now we need to do it more consistently.
“With our strengthened football leadership team now in place, we are looking forward to working hand-in-hand with Erik to achieve our shared ambitions for this football club.”

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo furious with team-mate for what he spotted him doing at gym
body: Cristiano Ronaldo's former Real Madrid and Juventus team-mate Sami Khedira has revealed the rule that the Portuguese star created after spotting a young player's gym habit
Cristiano Ronaldo laid down a strict rule for one of his young team-mates in the gym.

Former Juventus midfielder Sami Khedira spent more than six seasons with Ronaldo as their paths crossed at Real Madrid, as well as in Turin. The pair won plenty of trophies together, including three league titles and the Champions League, but the former Germany international also watched how Ronaldo’s role changed over the years.

Having experienced the former Manchester United forward become a Real Madrid legend, Khedira was greeted with a wiser version of Ronaldo at Juventus. The World Cup winner revealed how Ronaldo once gave some stern advice to a young star after spotting his gym habit.
“I saw two different Cristiano Ronaldos,” Khedira told Rio Ferdinand ’s FIVE YouTube Channel. “One when he was with Real Madrid, when he was a bit younger, and his ego was maybe a bit too much.
“Then he came to Juventus. When he came into the dressing room, he was interacting with all his team-mates and trying to help them as well. He’s an inspirational character.

“When he came to Juventus, Federico Chiesa was a fantastic young player. [Chiesa] had his phone in his hand and was walking into the gym and Cristiano looked at him like, ‘What are you doing? Where are you going?’

Recalling Chiesea’s reaction, Khedira said: “He was like, ‘I’m going to the gym.’” Ronaldo is claimed to have given Chiesa some clear instructions: “‘With your phone? Listen, you don’t need your phone. Go in the gym and work. Don’t do Instagram, don’t do any TikToks, focus on your work.’”

Khedira remembers that Chiesa hurriedly changed his mind and replied, “‘OK, OK, I’m going without my phone!’” This would have been during Chiesa’s first season at Juventus and the advice paid off, with the forward ending the 2020/21 campaign with 26 goal contributions for Juventus and a Euro 2020 winners’ medal.

It was not just Chiesa who Ronaldo influenced during training. Though Ronaldo’s time at Juventus may not have been a trophy-laden success, Khedira insists that he helped raise the team’s standards and explained how the former United hero differs from his online persona.

“Even the quality of training when he came to Juventus was like a different level afterwards because every single shot on target was like, ‘I need to score,’” Khedira explained to Ferdinand. “[He’d] play games for a bottle of wine or a dinner, he’s always a competitive guy but also a really friendly, nice and humble guy, from my point of view.

“All this Instagram or social media stuff, when he’s showing off his 150 cars and his rings, that’s not the real him. Maybe it’s kind of his role but in the locker room or if you go for dinner with him, he’s a funny and amazing guy.”

headline: 5 Man Utd stars on borrowed time with Jarrad Branthwaite 'annoyed' over transfer
body: A new centre-half is priority No.1 for Manchester United, and their failed pursuit of Jarrad Branthwaite has left the England international frustrated - with attention now turning to Matthijs de Ligt
Jarrad Branthwaite has grown frustrated with his stalling move to Manchester United - who are still looking to clear the decks to fund a summer move.

Everton centre-back Branthwaite has been on United's radar for some time after impressing in the Premier League and being called up to England's provisional Euro 2024 squad. United saw an opening offer of £35million plus add-ons rejected by the Toffees, who have slapped a £70million price tag on his head.
That has seen United turn their attention to Bayern Munich's Matthijs de Ligt, with the Dutchman available for around £40million and a deal in the offing.

The club remain fans of Branthwaite and would still like to get a deal over the line this summer, with incoming assistant manager Ruud van Nistelrooy a huge fan of the left-footed defender, and having worked with him previously at PSV Eindhoven.

They need exits though this summer and while they will listen to offers for all but a very select few. But among those they're most keen to push out and raise big funds with are the likes of Casemiro, Victor Lindelof, Harry Maguire, Antony and Jadon Sancho.

Saudi clubs are keen on ex-Real Madrid and Brazil star Casemiro but have baulked at a £30million valuation so far, while Lindelof has just one year left on his deal and could go for around £15million.
West Ham wanted Maguire last summer and agreed a fee only for him to stay put, but with Max Kilman on his way from Wolves for £40million, they may not return for the England man.
To bring in both Branthwaite and De Ligt would see both pushed down the pecking order, where fit-again Lisandro Martinez is Ten Hag's No.1 choice.

Winger Antony cost the Red Devils £86million, but they'll be getting nowhere near that back if they decide to sell the Brazilian this summer. Losing too much on the ex-Ajax man - of whom Ten Hag is a staunch advocate - may well be enough to keep him in situ at Old Trafford.

It's a different case with Sancho however. He spent the second half of last season on loan at Borussia Dortmund, helping them to a Champion League final, but with his relationship with Ten Hag at rock bottom, unless there is a drop in the tension between the two, he's likely to be pushed out again - if they can find a buyer.

headline: opinionSir Jim Ratcliffe's ruthless Man Utd overhaul means little without success after Ten Hag extension
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has ensured Manchester United have undergone a significant transformation after becoming co-owner and his stance will mean little if the Red Devils don't find success
Sir Jim Ratcliffe is no stranger to bold rhetoric. But Manchester United's perceived saviour must find a way of translating his grandiose words into the hard currency of success at Old Trafford.

Ratcliffe has wasted little time in transforming the set-up at United, insisting the environment at the club was ultimately to blame for the drift and turmoil that has blighted the club in the 11 years since Sir Alex Ferguson retired. Appointing a new CEO in Omar Berrada, new sporting director in Dan Ashworth and new technical director in Jason Wilcox shows Ratcliffe's determination to build the best possible structure for long-term success at United after what he branded a “slow degradation” over the past decade.

In a matter of months, Ratcliffe has done more to engage with United supporters and be open about his intentions for the club that despised majority owners the Glazers have done in nearly 20 years in charge.

While the Glazers have chosen a policy of omerta, Ratcliffe has gone the opposite way, meeting with fan representatives and local community leaders, to gauge their perspective and ascertain how best to work with them as he plots United's route back to the top.

But Ratcliffe knows actions speak louder than words and that, ultimately, he and his team will be judged on how United perform on the pitch, rather than on soundbites and a willingness to ingratiate themselves with the right people.

What Ratcliffe has publicly acknowledged, which has been evident for some time but allowed to continue at United, is the flagrant overspending on players worth nowhere near the fees paid for them, coupled with the failure to bring sufficient money in for those the club decides to let go.

Speaking last month, Ratcliffe said: “Since the day Sir Alex Ferguson and David Gill retired, 11 seasons ago, if you compare United with Real Madrid, who have consistently performed well, the net spend on players at United is £1.1billion. At Real Madrid it's £200m [so United have spent ] immensely more - £900m more.”

In another recent interview, Ratcliffe outlined his desire to take United to the level of Real, indisputably the biggest club in Europe, with a peerless 15 European Cups to their name, while acknowledging it will take many years to achieve that stated aim. Ratcliffe also gave praise to Manchester City chairman Khaldoon Al Mubarak, describing him as “an extremely good businessman" who "runs a really good football club” - the inference being the model of United's rivals is one the fallen giants must strive to emulate.

There is a mood of optimism and change among United fans, following the arrival of Ratcliffe, who has shown his ruthless streak with his controversial plan to cull 250 of the club's 1,100-strong employees, to cut costs and improve efficiency at the club. Such a move, allied to his propensity for firing off emails to United staff about the untidiness of some departments at the club and the need for every employee to raise standards in all areas, may not have endeared Ratcliffe to the Old Trafford workforce.

But Ratcliffe, one of Britain's richest men, estimated to be worth £29bn, is not interested in a popularity contest. The 71-year-old is a ruthless businessman, who has conducted a forensic audit of every aspect at United and is embarking on what he deems are necessary measures to make the team and the club one of the best again, domestically and in Europe.

That target was outlined by Ten Hag, speaking after it was confirmed United had triggered an option to extend his existing contract until 2026. That extension affords Ten Hag an element of security, but a similarly poor start to the season – United lost eight times in the league by Christmas last year – would test Ratcliffe's resolve to keep faith with him and leave him under pressure to appoint a new manager.

While Ratcliffe's PR has been sound since taking charge of football operations at United, he and his team will be judged on how they perform in this summer's transfer window and whether the changes made behind the scenes yield the expected results on the pitch and make the team competitive and relevant again, after more than a decade of dormancy.

headline: Erik ten Hag's Man Utd in-tray: Five problems that need immediate fix after new deal
body: Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag has plenty to do now that he's committed his future to the club until 2026. And on that note, here's what we reckon should be top of his to-do pile
Erik ten Hag has signed a new deal at Manchester United, which means he can finally get to work.

After overseeing arguably the club's worst-ever campaign in Premier League history last season, Ten Hag has plenty to do to get United out of the funk they've seemed so incapable of escaping over the past year or so. His side ended up eighth in the table, a whopping 31 points behind champions Manchester City, and lost 19 games in all competitions.

Last month's FA Cup final triumph, and the performance that went with it, provided a much-needed mood lift after nine months of doom and gloom, but it wasn't nearly enough to sweep their torrid season under the rug. As such, the next few months could be make or break for the Dutchman.
With that in mind, here are five things Ten Hag needs to sort out as soon as possible after extending his stay at Old Trafford to ensure next season is plane sailing.

First and foremost, Ten Hag needs to address the elephant in the room: Sir Jim Ratcliffe doesn't really want him. Almost as soon as the billionaire's minority stake in the club was confirmed at the start of the year, rumours started swirling that he was lining up replacements for the Dutchman.

The club then spent a couple of weeks after the season's end speaking to other managers, including former Chelsea boss Thomas Tuchel, before ultimately deciding to stick rather than twist. Such overt flirtation with other coaches suggests the axe could fall on Ten Hag's neck as soon as United hit another rough patch, so the former Ajax boss must find a way to convince Ratcliffe he's worth sticking with, and fast.

There are plenty of holes to patch in United's squad, particularly at the back and in midfield. The club have been pushing for a new centre-back, with the likes of Matthijs de Ligt, Jarrad Branthwaite and Marc Guehi on their radar, and are strongly linked with a move for PSG midfielder Manuel Ugarte.

Nabbing two or three high-quality players this summer could be the difference between a strong start to the season and a tepid one, so getting his ducks in order here should be a top priority for Ten Hag.

Similarly, getting the futures of the likes of Jadon Sancho, Casemiro and Harry Maguire sorted needs to be done ASAP, with all three rumoured to be on the chopping block. Sancho's issues with Ten Hag are well documented, and failure to either get rid of or patch things up with the Englishman could cause serious problems. Meanwhile, Casemiro and Maguire, both of whom are on huge wages, will need to be moved on if United sign new players in their positions

FA Cup win notwithstanding, the mood around Old Trafford is positively grim at the moment. Confidence has arguably never been lower, not only amongst the players but also amongst the supporters, and Ten Hag needs to address this problem sharpish.

It'll take a lot of work to banish the ghosts of last season, but a strong, positive pre-season, coupled with a few smart signings and sensible departures could inject a little life and belief back into the squad. If he can get the players firing on all cylinders, the fans, and more importantly, Ratcliffe, will be back on his side in no time.

Marcus Rashford's form last season was concerning. The 26-year-old scored just eight goals in all competitions, with just two of them coming before Christmas.

The fact that he bagged 30 goals the season before goes to show how vital it'll be to get the best out of him, and how much United's season could hinge on which version of Rashford turns up at the start of the campaign next month. If Ten Hag can find a way to turn Rashford from a purple patch player into a ruthlessly consistent difference-maker then he'll be on easy street - and it'll take a little pressure off Rasmus Hojlund's shoulders too!

United suffered 60 different injuries last season, and losing key players like Varane, Hojlund, Lisandro Martinez, Mason Mount, Christian Eriksen, Luke Shaw and Casemiro for long periods hamstrung them and stopped them from ever getting into any sort of rhythm.

Preventing the same thing from happening next season is an absolute must, and whether that means tweaking training methods, leaning more on the medical team, or being a tad more patient with recovery times - as, reportedly, wasn't the case last season - then Ten Hag really ought to do it.

headline: Jadon Sancho now has big decision to make after Erik ten Hag signs new Man Utd deal
body: Jadon Sancho was shut out by Erik ten Hag after the duo fell out last season, with the winger's future at Manchester United now up in the air after the Dutchman signed a contract extension
Jadon Sancho must rethink his plans if he's to have a future at Manchester United after Erik ten Hag put pen to paper on a new contract.

Ten Hag has signed a two-year contract extension with the Red Devils despite his disappointing second season in charge. That puts Sancho in an awkward position, with the winger having fallen out with the Dutchman last September.

Ten Hag had left Sancho out of his squad to play away at Arsenal due to what he described as poor training performances. The England international hit back at those claims, even accusing his manager of lying. Sancho was subsequently shipped out on loan to Borussia Dortmund, where he impressed. But he is now back at United, with the Bundesliga side unable to afford the fee it would take to bring him back permanently.

Mirror Football reported last month that Sancho would be willing to return to United, but only if Ten Hag was sacked. That obviously will not now happen, with the Dutchman set to remain for the long-term.

Sancho is thought to be reluctant to give up on his United career, though he is said to realise that he has no future under Ten Hag. He is keen to remain playing at the highest level, having starred in Dortmund's run to the Champions League final.

A return to Signal Iduna Park would likely be his best option, though that would likely have to be on another loan deal. Sancho could of course try to force his way into Ten Hag's plans, though the United boss has already hinted he is ready to sanction the winger's exit.

“So let's say this - yesterday he played very well and he's a very good player,” said Ten Hag after Dortmund's win in the semi-finals of the Champions League. “Yesterday he showed why Manchester United bought him.
"And he showed he represents a high value for Manchester United, which is good. I'm happy for Jadon, for the performance yesterday and we'll see what is going to happen in the future.”
In a further sign that Sancho should prepare to leave Old Trafford this summer, Ten Hag has made it clear he has the full backing of club chiefs over his vision for the squad and recruitment.

“I am very pleased to have reached agreement with the club to continue working together. Looking back at the past two years, we can reflect with pride on two trophies and many examples of progression from where we were when I joined," he said.
“However, we must also be clear that there is still lots of hard work ahead to reach the levels expected of Manchester United, which means challenging for English and European titles.
"In my discussions with the club, we have found complete unity in our vision for reaching those goals, and we are all strongly committed to making that journey together.”
The question is whether Sancho is ready to return and work with Ten Hag again?

headline: New Newcastle sporting director's plan that Man Utd overlooked comes to light
body: Newcastle have wasted no time in replacing Dan Ashworth - bringing in Paul Mitchell as their sporting director - with the Englishman previously on Manchester United's shortlist
Newcastle have moved quickly to land Paul Mitchell as their sporting director - replacing Dan Ashworth.

The Magpies had one of the best domestic operators at the helm at St James' Park before Manchester United turned his head. After a stubborn stand off a resolution was found that allowed Ashworth to head to Old Trafford - but Newcastle haven't rested on their laurels.

Those within the game may argue that the north east club haven't had to settle at all, in fact Mitchell too was on Sir Jim Ratcliffe's radar when he considered who to bring in as his new sporting director.

Mitchell's stock has continued to rise throughout his career, doing impressive work at Southampton, Tottenham and Monaco. His time in France broadened his horizon and he helped the Ligue 1 outfit to land players who've gone on to achieve huge things, whilst working within a budget and keeping the club's academy at the forefront of everything they do.

At Tottenham he, despite criticism from his own coaches, chose to sign Son-Heung min. The South Korean has gone on to become one of the best buys in modern Premier League history and Mitchell certainly takes every element of the club into consideration when making any decision.

When he was in the south of France Mitchell did an interview with club media and said the overall plan was: "Finding a great balance of developing and exposing our young talent from the academy, to our signings, to our investment and integrating nicely into the more mature elements of our group."

It was Mitchell for example who created a thriving environment that allowed Aurélien Tchouaméni to flourish. The French midfielder eventually left for Real Madrid and could end up earning Monaco €100million.

Tchouaméni is still a young player and that has been central to Mitchell's plans. He said: "We want to give young players an opportunity to grow and develop" but admitted that "with any young group consistency is a hard balance to find."

At Newcastle he will find a host of young talents who continue to mature and blossom. Some of those are already leading lights at St James' Park - the likes of Alexander Isak, 24, Anthony Gordon, 23 and Sandro Tonali, 24, all have their best years ahead of them.
Lewis Miley, the 18-year-old midfielder who had a breakout year last term, is among those who may benefit from Mitchell's arrival and influence.

Mitchell made it known that, in order to compliment and aid the young talent, having experienced leaders in the dressing room to drive the culture was key. Monaco signed Cesc Fabregas from Chelsea and he played at the club well into his 30s, remaining a sounding board for the whole squad.

The sporting director said: "The attitude of our older players is the key fabric that in the dressing room brings it all together." Newcastle only have two players outside of the back four who are 30 or over with their age profile incredibly lower. The capture of a player, more for their IQ and experience, could therefore be on the cards, especially as the club, who don't have a winning history of late, attempt to join clubs who deal in success annually.

Not solely limited to recruitment and selling though, Mitchell has made it clear that every area will be exhausted to find little wins for the team. "More important for me it is off the pitch - driving standards in each and every department," he said. "Psychology, sport science, medicine, nutrition, the way we travel, the way we refuel. Every element we need to keep pushing to its maximum."

If the Red Devils have been accused of not doing their due diligence over the years when it comes to transfer deaings, Mitchell cannot be accused of the same. He's underlined the need to have a clear plan in place and not freak out after a poor run of results of an injury in a key position.

Newcastle have struck a good balance in the market since their Saudi owners came on board and their new sporting director's philosophy is to do exactly the same. "People look at modern recruitment as very reactionary and very emotional - when I came to Monaco and other clubs it has to be more premeditated," he told Sky Sports.

Ashworth, for all the brilliant plaudits he's enjoyed, has been accused of failing to do the necessary work when signing Tonali. He was the marquee signing from AC Milan 12 months ago but a history of gambling issues meant he was quickly banned and has barely featured.

He is expected to come good - but Newcastle have seen a very expensive asset sit on the sidelines for months. Mitchell believes "investments, if made badly, can haunt and stop progression for a long, long time after that."

One investment he made, but was criticised for, was signing Son whilst at Tottenham. Doubts existed of his finishing, but Mitchell didn't believe that sentiment had legs and the strike record of the South Korean showed that sporting director was more than within his rights to back himself - something he will no doubt continue to do in the north east.

He said: "I took a lot of criticism in my first year at Tottenham, Sonny was at the centre of that, which was a bit of a learning for me. Players are humans, they need time, need to be able to settle. Sonny had a great record at Hamburg and Leverkusen, but there was this narrative that he wasn't a good finisher and I said to a staff member 'you're wrong' because his history shows he is a very astute finisher. What we've seen since that first year is everything we saw."

headline: Four Man Utd stars quit club after Erik ten Hag 'brutally axed them from dressing room'
body: Erik ten Hag isn't exactly one for taking prisoners and has spent the last two years making considerable changes to Manchester United's first team, including banishing certain players
Four of the five players Erik ten Hag banished from Manchester United's first team dressing room have now left the club.

Since arriving at Old Trafford in 2022, Ten Hag has done his utmost to mould the squad in his image and hasn't been afraid to make some bold, and often brutal, decisions. He dropped Cristiano Ronaldo, ostracised Jadon Sancho and let David de Gea disappear into the void, all in the name of improving the side, as well as the harmony within the squad.

But it isn't just the big names who have fallen foul of the Dutchman's ruthlessness. Just a few weeks after taking over, he reportedly axed five stars from the senior dressing room to free up space for the players he'd brought in that summer.

Phil Jones, Brandon Williams, Axel Tuanzebe, Tegen Mengi and Shola Shoretire were allegedly all ordered to train, eat and change with the academy squad, a move which, unsurprisingly, pushed most of them towards the door. Jones was the first to leave in May 2023 and decided to hang up his boots on his way at just 31.
Mengi, now 22, followed suit a few months later, joining newly-promoted Luton Town, and a week after that Tuanzebe, 26 was gone too, with the defender signing for Ipswich Town.
It left just Williams, 23, and Shoretire, 20, as the only two axed first-teamers left. But last month, two became one, with Williams departing following the expiration of his contract.

Shoretire, 20, won't be far behind, having grown frustrated with his lack of first-team opportunities at the club. He reportedly has a contract offer from United on the table but isn't expected to sign it.

headline: Man Utd to sign 'exciting' Slovakia star from under the nose of Premier League rivals
body: Manchester United have overhauled their recruitment department and that is now set to pay dividends as the Red Devils close in on signing Slovakian wonderkid Samuel Lusale
Manchester United are closing on the signing of Slovakian wonderkid Samuel Lusale.

Lusale is currently on the books of Crystal Palace, having joined the Eagles three years ago. The 16-year-old impressed enough for Palace's Under-18s side to earn a call-up to the Under-17s Euros in May.

He played in all three group games at the tournament, though Slovakia finished bottom of their group. Lusale mainly played in the Under-18s Premier League, helping Palace to finish sixth in the South Division.
His performances have clearly caught the eye of United, who are now working hard to bring him to Old Trafford. The teenager is already represented by Roc Nation, the talent group founded by Jay-Z.

According to the Manchester Evening News, United are 'close' to adding Lusale to their youth team. English teams are restricted in their recruitment at academy level by Brexit regulations which prohibit them from signing players under the age of 18 from overseas clubs.

It appears that United will have a wonderkid on their hands if they do complete the deal for Lusale. Roc Nation’s Global director of football recruitment, Nathan Campbell: “Samuel is a very exciting attacking player who has an abundance of ability.
“He's a late developer, having come into the academy system at a later age, but it's so exciting to contemplate the incredible heights he can reach as he matures both physically and technically.”

Signing Lusale would certainly fit into controlling co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe's vision for United's future recruitment. Back in February, he made it clear that the academy would be a key part of his plans for the future.

“Recruitment in the modern game is critical. Manchester United have clearly spent a lot of money but they haven’t done as well as some other clubs. So when I was talking about being best in class in all aspects of football, recruitment is clearly top of the list,” he said.

“We’re probably still debating what precisely is the style of football we want to play. If you look at Manchester City, they know precisely what the style of football is they want to play and all 11 teams at the club play the same formula.

"We need to do that, but I think in terms of the nature of the players, you want Manchester United types of players: attacking football, exciting football, bringing the youth through. You want players that are committed.

"You want players that play 90 minutes — those are the types of players you want playing for Manchester United. The academy is really, really important for us. It’s probably the most successful academy in football in terms of number of players that have come through.

“We’ll decide that style, plus the CEO, sporting director, probably the recruitment guys, what the style of football is and that will be the Manchester United style of football, and the coach will have to play that style. In modern football, you need to decide what’s your path and stick to your path.”

body: Manchester United have confirmed that Erik ten Hag has signed a new contract extension at Old Trafford, ending speculation about his future in the new footballing setup at the club
Erik ten Hag has signed a new contract extension with Manchester United until 2026.

Ten Hag was given the green light to continue as United boss last month, after being left in limbo for two-and-a-half weeks after winning the FA Cup. United conducted an end-of-season review and talked to other candidates to replace Ten Hag, but ultimately decided to stick with the 54-year-old Dutchman.

“Looking back at the past two years, we can reflect with pride on two trophies and many examples of progression from where we were when I joined.

“In my discussions with the club, we have found complete unity in our vision for reaching those goals, and we are all strongly committed to making that journey together.”

Dan Ashworth, United's newly-appointed sporting director, said: “With two trophies in the past two seasons, Erik has reinforced his record as one of the most consistently successful coaches in European football.
“While the club’s review of last season highlighted areas for improvement, it also reached a clear conclusion that Erik was the best partner for us to work with in driving up standards and outcomes.
“This group of players and staff have already shown they are capable of competing and winning at the top level. Now we need to do it more consistently.
“With our strengthened football leadership team now in place, we are looking forward to working hand-in-hand with Erik to achieve our shared ambitions for this football club.”
Ten Hag, who took over at United in 2022 when he joined from Ajax, had one year left on his £9million-a-year contract, with the option for an extra 12 months.
But once United decided to stick with him, after talking to potential replacements including former Bayern Munich boss Thomas Tuchel, they entered into talks over a new deal.

Erik ten Hag has signed a new contract at Manchester United.

The Dutchman was under severe pressure earlier this year after a miserable Premier League season. New co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe conducted a detailed review into his position and even spoke to potential replacements, with Thomas Tuchel among the candidates.

But Ratcliffe eventually chose to leave Ten Hag in situ at Old Trafford following the club's FA Cup success against rivals Manchester City at Wembley. That made it two trophies in two seasons for the Dutchman, and he has been rewarded with a new contract.

Ten Hag had one year left on his £9m-a-year deal, but has agreed a one-year extension, which sees his contract now run until the summer of 2026. He said: “I am very pleased to have reached agreement with the club to continue working together.

“Looking back at the past two years, we can reflect with pride on two trophies and many examples of progression from where we were when I joined. “In my discussions with the club, we have found complete unity in our vision for reaching those goals, and we are all strongly committed to making that journey together.”

Ten Hag's deal comes after new sporting director Dan Ashworth finally arrived at the club earlier this week from Newcastle. It's believed United paid £12million to end his gardening leave and finally get him through the door.

Van Nistelrooy held two rounds of talks to replace Vincent Kompany at Turf Moor, but elected to return to Old Trafford instead. Go Ahead Eagles manager Rene Hake is also joining as an assistant head coach too.
One member of Ten Hag’s staff that is on the way out is Benni McCarthy. His contract expired this summer and he has departed to pursue his own managerial career.

Ten Hag is under no illusions that he will need to improve on the club’s fortunes next term after a grossly underwhelming Premier League campaign. They slumped to eighth, losing 14 games in the process.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo may face Euro 2024 punishment after penalty drama and 'illegal' move
body: Cristiano Ronaldo looks to have broken marketing rules at the European Championships as the Portugal forward collaborates with a fitness brand that published his stats on social media
Cristiano Ronaldo could find himself in hot water with UEFA after his involvement in 'ambush marketing' following Portugal's last 16 victory.
The Euro 2016 winners needed penalties to see off Slovakia, on a tumultuous night for Ronaldo, where there was no shortage of tears and no little relief.

Afterwards Ronaldo had his heart rate data shared on social media. In doing so the Al-Nassr star showcased his collaboration with the fitness company WHOOP - who design wearable devices that track things like your heart rate, athletic performance, and sleep score.

The practice is illegal as it sees a company attempt to associate their product or services with an event, in this case Euro 2024, which already has its own official sponsors. The 39-year-old is wearing one of their devices during his outings at the Euros and his heart rate data during Portugal's penalty shootout win was published by the company on Tuesday.

Ricardo Fort - the former head of global sponsorships at Visa and Coca-Cola - has claimed on social media that the post was a clear example of ambush marketing and should be met with a fine for both player and company.
He said: "This chart has been circulating today. Cristiano and WHOOP is ambush marketing to Euro 2024. It is illegal and both the player and the company should be fined."

Fort later added: "The post is about a UEFA matches, uses the names of the two national teams playing, score, and a player on the field. They are implying an association with the event and that is illegal. Not having 'a competitor as a sponsor' isn't a reason to tolerate infringements."

An example of a player facing a punishment for such an act came during Euro 2012 when Nicklas Bendtner pulled up his shirt as he celebrated to reveal a pair of Paddy Power branded underpants. The Dane was later fine £80,000 and banned for one competitive game by UEFA.
Ronaldo endured a mixed night in the last 16 encounter but is likely to start in Portugal's quarter-final showdown with France on Friday.

Former England captain Alan Shearer insists: "I don’t think Martinez has a choice - Ronaldo plays. We saw that in their third game when Portugal had already qualified, only three players had started from the previous 11 and Ronaldo was one of them.

"He’s 39 years-old and he’s taking all the free-kicks, he took that penalty and missed it, although he deserves great credit for the way he took the first penalty in the shootout because the pressure on him was absolutely huge.
"But Martinez doesn’t have a choice, if Ronaldo is fit Ronaldo plays. That’s the rule, I’m afraid."

headline: Mason Mount 'breaks up with' former McDonald's worker girlfriend
body: Manchester United striker Mason Mount has been dating ex-fast-food employee turned TikTok star Freya Tidy for just three months, but now it's reportedly 'all over'
Mason Mount has reportedly split from TikToker Freya Tidy.

The Manchester United striker and former McDonald's employee are "all over", according to insiders. After just three months together, the 25-year-old football star has unfollowed the influencer on all his social media platforms, and she's done the same.

He was only recently spotted alongside the content creator beauty after missing out on a space in England's Euro 2024 squad. The then-couple were pictured looking happier than ever in Greater Manchester before climbing into Mason's £120,000 Land Rover.

"It looks like it’s all over," a source told The Sun. "Mason has unfollowed her on all social platforms and she’s done the same to him." Neither have publicly spoken about the reported end of their relationship, while Freya remains active on her social media.

She boasts over 287,000 Instagram followers and a whopping 761,500 TikTok followers, sharing snippets of her daily life with followers. Recent posts include "get ready with me for lunching", "double denim" and "everyday make-up."

She also loves to share glimpses of her life on Instagram - flaunting whatever outfit she's donned that day. Freya is from Essex and worked at McDonald's as a teenager before joining a dance college which helped her amass a large TikTok following, where she shares dance and lip-sync videos, according to the Daily Star.

Mount signed up for a dating app last year and a source told The Sun: "Mason is all about football but is also looking to find the right girl to settle down with. He is looking for a genuine connection and hopes that a few dates in the capital can help him find The One. Mason has taken his time after the break-up but is not going to rush into anything."

Mount, who joined United for £55million from Chelsea last summer, has struggled to make his mark in Manchester during an injury-hit campaign. He's been single since parting ways with his model ex-girlfriend Chloe Wealleans-Watts in 2022. The pair had been together for five years after first meeting in Dubai in 2017.

headline: Dan Ashworth's first act as Man Utd director will be music to Erik ten Hag's ears
body: Manchester United are set to continue their transformation on the pitch after an overhaul in their hierarchy and Dan Ashworth appears to have ambitious transfer plans for Erik ten Hag's side
Manchester United may have a modest transfer budget to kickstart the summer but have ambitious plans to strengthen Erik ten Hag's squad in the coming weeks.

Dan Ashworth's work begins with immediate effect after United were able to agree a deal with Newcastle for his services. The sporting director's arrival sees the club's new football hierarchy of Ashworth, Jason Wilcox and new CEO Omar Berrada able to begin in earnest to leave their imprint at Old Trafford amid Sir Jim Ratcliffe's overhaul since investing.

The transformation may have once left Ten Hag with some trepidation, but the Dutchman will be reassured by his side's plans. The club have previously backed their coach with signings he has valued to mixed success.

United's move for Antony in particular has drawn criticism given the Brazilian's inability to kick on in the north west. But after the meeting in Ibiza where Ten Hag was told he would not be sacked, the former Ajax boss determined that he would be unwilling to relinquish control of his role in identifying possible transfer targets. United's boss previously insisted on a clause that would allow him to sign-off on transfers.

The 54-year-old will feel vindicated that his team are eyeing Dutch defender Matthijs de Ligt, who he worked with at Ajax. Ten Hag will also be relieved to see United have ambitious plans despite Ratcliffe's assertion it will take “two or three summer windows” for the club to see a significant improvement.

United intend to prioritise three positions – centre-back, midfielder and striker – this summer, despite profit and sustainability rule ensuring just a £50million budget to start with. The 13-times Premier League champions are exploring a £55m move for Bayern Munich star De Ligt, after already making a bid for Everton central defender Jarrad Branthwaite of £35m plus £8m in add-ons.

In midfield, efforts have been made to scout Wolves' Brazil international Joao Gomes, in addition to Benfica teenager Joao Neves. PSG midfielder Manuel Ugarte has also drawn United's interest and the club are pushing to sign the Uruguayan.

Despite landing Rasmus Hojlund last summer, United's hope of landing a new forward to relieve some of the burden on the Denmark international is no secret. Dutch striker Joshua Zirkzee of Bologna, is a potential signing who appears to be on the move this summer.

To be able to pull-off such signings, Ashworth and his team will also prove busy in facilitating players head in the opposite direction. There is an ambition to boost United's transfer budget by as much as £200m.

That would see the Manchester club return fees for seven players. United hope to offload Casemiro, Victor Lindelof, Harry Maguire, Christian Eriksen, Antony, Jadon Sancho and Mason Greenwood. There is willingness to listen to good offers for other members of United's squad too however - even Bruno Fernandes could depart should a sizeable offer arrive, but he is expected to stay and sign a new deal.
Raphael Varane, Anthony Martial and Brandon Williams have already left this summer. United saw little boon to their funds as each left for free following their expiration of their contracts however.

headline: Newcastle United seal coup with replacement for Dan Ashworth after Man Utd move
body: Newcastle have confirmed that Paul Mitchell will be their new sporting director after Dan Ashworth left following a resolution with Manchester United over his future finally being reached
Newcastle have announced that Paul Mitchell is their new sporting director - replacing Dan Ashworth after his move to Manchester United.

Mitchell himself was linked with the same role at Old Trafford having performed impressive work, especially in the transfer window, at the likes of Tottenham and Ligue 1 outfit Monaco. He will now play a huge role in the summer recruitment at St James' Park.

Mitchell enjoyed a prominent role at Southampton, which later led to him working at Tottenham where he signed the likes of Son-Heung min. He's also helped RB Leipzig, Red Bull Soccer International and more recently, Monaco.

Mitchell said: "It's with immense pride that I accept the responsibility of being Newcastle United's new sporting director. I've seen the recent growth and ambition of the club. This, plus the amazing fan base, made the decision to join an easy one. I can’t wait to get started and help continue the organisation's growth and long-term competitiveness in all areas of elite football performance."

Newcastle had only hired Ashworth following their Saudi takeover in recent years and his expertise helped land some major names, which coincided with the club qualifying for the Champions League. Ashworth though made his desire to move to Manchester clear.
That served as a blow to the Magpies, who placed him on gardening leave and stood firm amid a compensation battle with the Red Devils, which has now been resolved.

They've moved quick to land a replacement with Mitchell's stock immensely high. He will have a say in some major decisions over the coming months as Newcastle look to continue with their ambitious plan all whilst remaining financially compliant. There is talk of them cashing in on a big name this summer, the likes of Alexander Isak, to ensure their long-term plan remains on course.

Darren Eales, Newcastle's CEO, added: "We are delighted to welcome Paul to Newcastle United. He brings a successful track record and wealth of experience to the club. His extensive and diverse experience in football leadership, cultural change and recruitment mean he is the ideal person to lead our sporting directorate.
"We look forward to working with Paul and supporting him in our pursuit of long-term, sustainable success."

body: Manchester United could kickstart the summer transfer window after finally landing Dan Ashworth with Arsenal and Liverpool also expected to be busy as Premier League clubs go to work in the market
The summer transfer window is expected to ramp up once Euro 2024 comes to a close - with several names putting themselves in the shop window.

Manchester United's business will be aided by the arrival of Dan Ashworth as sporting director with Erik ten Hag also penning a new deal. Their interest in Matthijs de Ligt remains strong as they look to make the Bayern Munich defender one of their first signings.

Meanwhile, both Arsenal and Liverpool are keen to close the gap on champions Manchester City through summer signings with Nico Williams, who has shone for Spain, among those linked with a move to one of the Premier League's.

Elsewhere in Europe, Real Madrid have set their sights on Arsenal star William Saliba and Bayern Munich have agreed a £43million deal to sign Fulham's Joao Palinha - 12 months are their initial efforts failed.
Keep up to date with all the latest transfer news below...

Liverpool are prepared to meet Nico Williams's release clause of just under £50m, according to El Nacional. The winger has starred for Spain at Euro 2024, prompting plenty of interest from the Premier League and beyond.

WIlliams has shown no indication of being unhappy at Athletic Club, but some appear ready to test the water and see if he fancies a move away from Bilbao. Liverpool are said to be one of them, with Chelsea and Barcelona also linked.

Arsenal are said to have seen a £42million bid accepted for Italian defender Riccardo Calafiori. That offer has proven enough to persuade Bologna to part ways with their star after the Serie A side had previously turned down a bid just short of £40m.
Bologna are reported by TuttoMercatoWeb to have 'said yes'. Calafiori is also said to have been convinced by the Gunners' proposal and a move could unfold quickly.

We'll be back with you tomorrow morning, and hope you will join us then.
Goodnight!
Former Manchester United striker Teddy Sheringham is not convinced Matthijs de Ligt is the answer to the club's defensive issues.
“I don’t know if Matthijs de Ligt would be a good addition to the United defence,” Sheringham told Poker Sites.
"“I think United need some experience in their back line, ideally someone with Premier League experience.
"He’s obviously a very good player and we all remember him from his time at Ajax, but I don’t think he should be the number one priority at the moment for the club."
Getafe are pushing for Real Madrid youngster Peter Federico as they move on from Mason Greenwood.
Greenwood is expected to leave Manchester United permanently after a year on loan in La Liga, though Getafe are not believed to have the financial might to compete for his signature.
Federico, who spent part of last season on loan at Valencia, will join on an initial loan according to Marca (via Football Espana).
Arsenal are expected to strengthen this summer, but manager Mikel Arteta has offered a reminder of the realities of the transfer market.
The Gunners have had a slow start to the transfer window, but have confirmed a permanent deal for goalkeeper David Raya following a successful loan.
"I think both ways [players coming in and going out of the club]. There are things that we have to improve, that's for sure and we are going to try to," Arteta told ESPN.

"But the market is tricky. We have been very aggressive, we are very determined and we have a clear idea obviously of what we want to do. It will come down to finding the right agreements at the right time."
Germany and Bayern Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer isn't ruling out a move to Major League Soccer after speaking to former colleague Bastian Schweinsteiger.
Schweinsteiger spent time with Chicago Fire at the end of his career, having been a team-mate of Neuer for club and country.

"You have to think it through carefully," Neuer added in an interview with Welt in which he described MLS as an option. "Also because they play a lot on artificial turf there, which is not ideal for a goalkeeper“
Shandon Baptiste is set to join Luton town after leaving Brentford on a free.
According to the Evening Standard, the Grenada international midfielder will sign a three-year deal with Rob Edwards' side.
Baptiste played 55 times in the Premier League for Brentford, scoring twice.
Michael Olise is set for a Bayern Munich medical this week, according to Sky Germany.
The Crystal Palace winger is expected to sign a contract until 2029, with Joao Palhinha also headed to Bayern from the Premier League.
Olise's move comes despite interest from a number of English clubs, both last summer and this.
Sturm Graz will pay a club record £4m for Arsenal striker Mika Biereth, according to The Athletic.
Arsenal are reported to have a sell-on clause for the Danish striker, who will leave North London without making a competitive appearance for the Gunners.
Biereth spent the second half of last season on loan in Austria, scoring nine times in 22 Sturm appearances.
Joshua Kimmich has been linked with Arsenal and Liverpool this summer, but it now appears Paris Saint-Germain and Manchester City could attempt to steal a march.
According to RMC Sport (via Get French Football News), PSG have turned their attention to the German after running into difficulties in their pursuit of Joao Neves.
Bayern Munich's move for Joao Palhinha is expected to push Kimmich down the pecking order, and if he moves to Paris it could help fill the gap expected to be left by Manuel Ugarte's departure.
Olympique Lyonnais have brought in another Premier League star, paying Nottingham Forest £27m for Moussa Niakhate.
Senegal centre-back Niakhate, 28, follows Orel Mangala in moving to the Ligue 1 side and has signed a deal until the summer of 2028.
Lyon also completed a permanent move for West Ham winger Said Benrahma earlier in the summer after an impressive loan.
Ethan Ingram is set to join Dundee after deciding to leave West Brom.
Mirror Football reported last month that the former England U20 international had suitors in League One and Scotland after entering the final weeks of his deal at the Hawthorns.
And we revealed on Wednesday morning that Ingram, 21, is now closing in on a move to the Scottish Premiership after spending the last few weeks weighing up his options.
