Leeds have rejected a £30milion offer from Brighton for Georginio Rutter, claiming it falls short of their valuation of the French forward.
Leeds paid Hoffenheim £36million for Rutter 18 months ago and feel his value has not gone down when he has four years left on his contract.
Rutter, 22, managed eight goals and 15 assists last season in the Championship and boss Daniel Farke feels he adds creativity to his side.
Meanwhile, Jamie Shackleton has completed his free transfer to Sheffield United, ending his 15-year stint at Leeds.
The versatile Shackleton, 24, can play defence or midfield and was at Leeds since the age of nine.
James Beadle has agreed a second loan move to Sheffield Wednesday.
The Brighton goalkeeper, an England youth international, played 19 times for the Owls in the Championship last season.
“James made a big impression at Sheffield Wednesday last season and enjoyed his loan spell there," Brighton technical director David Weir said.
“So this is a good move for him to continue to develop in an environment he knows well. We’ll be monitoring his progress throughout the season and we wish him well.”
According to reports on the continent, Leicester City are on the verge of adding Caleb Okoli to their ranks.
Italy under-21 international Okoli came through Atalanta's academy, and impressed on loan at Frosinone last season.
The defender's arrival comes as Steve Cooper's side also chase midfield reinforcements after losing Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall to Chelsea.
Wolves are leading the race to bring Kasper Schmeichel back to the Premier League.
Schmeichel is a free agent after finishing his one-year deal at Anderlecht and Wolves have made contact with the Denmark goalkeeper.
Schmeichel, 37, is also being tracked by a number of other Premier League clubs and is keen to return to England.
Nottingham Forest were keen on signing Schmeichel in January, but Anderlecht did not want to lose him as they challenged for the Belgian Pro League.
Schmeichel is now a free agent and will have no shortage of suitors after his starring role in Denmark’s march to the last 16 of Euro 2024.
Schmeichel is keen to come home to England and he spent the first 16 years of his professional career here, winning the Premier League and FA Cup with Leicester, before joining Nice in 2022.
West Ham had been eyeing up potential alternatives to Max Kilman, with Hull defender Jacob Greaves among them, but the Hammers have returned with an improved bid for Wolves' captain.
It is expected to be successful, providing a boost to new manager Julen Lopetegui, who is understood to have pushed for a reunion with his former charge.

Lopetegui's team have already cashed in on Thilo Kehrer this summer, with the German defender joining Monaco after a successful loan, while veteran Angelo Ogbonna left upon the expiry of his contract in June.
Arsenal aren't the only ones signing a new keeper, with Inter Milan also busy.
Josep Martinez is the new man, arriving for a medical ahead of what Sport Mediaset (via Football Italia) say will be a €13m move from Genoa.

26-year-old Martinez, who is expected to be a long-term successor to Yann Sommer, made his Spain debut in 2021 and was a regular for Genoa last term as they finished with the best defensive record in the bottom half of Serie A.
David Raya says it is a “dream come true” to sign for Arsenal on a permanent basis.

Spain keeper Raya, 28, was on loan last season from Brentford and now Arsenal have agreed a permanent deal with a £30m-plus option already in place. Raya replaced fans’ favourite Aaron Ramsdale as the club’s No1 and won the supporters over by winning the Premier League Golden Glove, keeping 16 league clean sheets in 41 games across all competitions.

Gunners keeper Raya became a huge hero when he was the star of the penalty shoot-out win over Porto in the Champions League. Raya said: “After a year on loan as a Gunner, I can finally say that I’m an Arsenal player for the coming years.

‌“I’m excited to see what the future holds but always living in and enjoying the present. It’s a dream come true to be here and I want to thank you for all the support you have already given me throughout the last year.”
Adrien Rabiot has decided that he wants to join Real Madrid, despite Liverpool and Newcastle both 'making a move' for the France international.
Rabiot, 29, is a free agent after his contract with Juventus expired and it's claimed that the Italian giants have given up on attempting to tie him down to a new deal.
Calciomercato report that Juve are now pushing ahead of sign Khephren Thuram from Nice. That suggests Rabiot will be on the move and his ideal destination is Real Madrid.
Former Arsenal defender Mikael Silvestre has admitted he is "surprised" by the Gunners' interest in Riccardo Calafiori, insisting they should be focusing on signing a new striker instead.
"You have Timber, Kiwior, Tomiyasu who can play at CB," Silvestre told bettingexpert.com. "Gabriel and Saliba haven't shown any signs of weakness. They've been super fit.
"I'd be surprised if Arsenal goes for another CB of that calibre (referring to Riccardo Calafiori). I don't think the club needs another CB.

"If you have to spend money you go ahead and do it on a No. 9. I think that should be an area that they should look at improving and to bring competition to the squad. No. 9 would be the priority in my view.

"Yeah they are on the right path. The problem is that you have to be able to continue and maintain the pressure on Manchester City and whoever is going to come into the race next season, if somebody can. You have to be resilient.
"Mikel has the desire to achieve something with Arsenal. He's fully committed. It's going to be tough but I'm sure he'll try hard."
According to the Telegraph, West Ham have made an improved £40m bid for Wolves captain Max Kilman.
Kilman is a top target for new West Ham boss Julen Lopetegui, who previously managed him at Wolves, and he is valued at £45m.
Brentford have also shown interest in Romania right-back Andrei Ratiu following his outstanding contribution at Euro 2024.
The blue-haired defender, who can play right back or right wing-back, excelled in Germany and is also on Brighton's radar.
Atalanta and other clubs from Serie A and the Bundesliga also like the player, who currently plays in La Liga with Rayo Vallecano.
Vallecano, however, are looking to tie him down to a new contract and are determined to fend off interest. No offers are yet to land on their table
Man United have reportedly agreed to sign defender Miguel Gutierrez from Real Madrid.
According to reports in Spain via Express, the Red Devils have agreed to pay the Spanish giants £34m for the left-back. But they need to wait before a move is formalised.

Gutierrez is currently with Girona - and helped the club reach the Champions League last season. Real Madrid retain a £6.7million buy-back clause. They are apparently set to activate that before selling Gutierrez straight on to the Red Devils.
Hull winger Jaden Philogene is attracting interest from a number of clubs both in the Premier League and across Europe and Chris Waddle believes he should move abroad.

“I think his game probably suits the continent rather than England,” Waddle said to Lord Ping. “I think he’ll have more freedom to express himself playing in Europe where he can focus on the things he does well and not have to worry as much about the defensive side of the game.

“For his development as a player, a move to Europe would also benefit him. Barcelona have been linked to him, which says it all about the type of player he is and could become. He’s going to have some wonderful options and he deserves them. If I was him, I’d go to a club in Spain or Germany.

“Hull paid £5 million for him, which is a lot of money for a Championship club but is starting to look like a real bargain. I’m certain that Aston Villa will have a sell-on clause on him after letting him go for that price. A lot of clubs are looking at him.

“He had a great season with Hull scoring twelve goals and laying on six assists. He’s only twenty-two, so the potential is massive. When I first saw him, I thought he looked like a player that was destined to reach the top of the game.

“I found it strange that Hull managed to get him because his potential was clear. He’ll obviously be sold for a lot more money than Hull paid for him, so it’s been a shrewd investment from them and a great bit of business.”
16-year-old defender Wes Okoduwa has signed a deal to stay at Wolves, with the Express and Star reporting that he rejected the chance to join Chelsea.
Celtic’s Marco Tilio has signed a new loan deal with Melbourne City which sees him remain in the A-League for another season.
The 22-year-old attacker signed for the Hoops on a five-year deal from the Australian club last summer for a transfer fee reported to be an A-League record.
However, he only made two appearances off the bench for the Parkhead side, against Motherwell and Hibernian.
Tilio joined Melbourne City on loan in February but injury restricted him to just four A-League appearances where he scored once.

The Australia international told City’s official website: “I’m so happy that I can extend my stay at City, this club has always felt like home to me, and I can’t wait to get back on the pitch and contribute to the team.

“Last season was a difficult one for me with injury, but I’ve been working hard to come back stronger and I’m looking forward to making more memorable moments together with my teammates and the City fans.”
Maxence Lacroix has reportedly turned down a contract offer from Wolfsburg amid links of a move to Liverpool.
The French centre-back, who's left-footed, has entered in the final 12 months of his deal and is attracting interest from across Europe and in the Premier League.

Reports from Italy state that Lacroix, 24, is niw exploring his options after rejecting the chance to sign a new deal with Wolfsburg. Crystal Palace, who are managed by ex-Wolfsburg boss Oliver Glasner, have also been tipped to sign him alongside Juventus and AC Milan.
Erik ten Hag has signed a new contract at Manchester United.

The Dutchman was under severe pressure earlier this year after a miserable Premier League season. New co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe conducted a detailed review into his position and even spoke to potential replacements, with Thomas Tuchel among the candidates.

But Ratcliffe eventually chose to leave Ten Hag in situ at Old Trafford following the club's FA Cup success against rivals Manchester City at Wembley. That made it two trophies in two seasons for the Dutchman, and he has been rewarded with a new contract.

headline: Wrexham suffers Paul Mullin injury blow as Ryan Reynolds' star man has spinal surgery
body: Star forward Paul Mullin will be sidelined for the start of Wrexham's domestic campaign for a second-straight season after undergoing spinal surgery last month

Wrexham striker Paul Mullin will miss the start of the League One season after undergoing a "minor spinal surgery." The 11-year English football veteran had the procedure performed in London last week, hoping to remedy longstanding issues in his hamstring and lower back.

"The club's three-time, back-to-back top scorer and player of the season has managed the injury through conservative treatment following three years of concern," Wrexham said in a statement. "However, during off-season training it became evident that this approach would not be able to continue and, following several consultations, it was determined that surgery would be the best way forward."

Mullin was raised in Litherland, a suburban community north of Liverpool's city centre, and spent time at the academies of Everton and Liverpool before signing his first professional contract with Huddersfield Town in 2013. The forward turned in a modest goal return with Morecambe and bounced around the lower levels of the Football League before a breakout loan stint at League Two Cambridge United.

After signing with Wrexham in 2021, Mullin became the talisman of Rob McElhenny and Ryan Reynolds ' revitalization of the club. Mullin was National League Player of the Year that season and helped the Dragons achieve successive promotions in 2022-23, scoring 88 goals in 128 appearances.

The fourth-year Wrexham man's injury also rules him out of Wrexham's preseason tour in the United States, where Mullin suffered a punctured lung against Manchester United and missed six weeks of action. This season's exhibition circuit, dubbed the "Wrex Coast Tour 2024" takes the Dragons to California for matchups against AFC Bournemouth (Santa Barbara) and Chelsea FC (Santa Clara) before heading north of the border to face Vancouver Whitecaps at BC Place.

"Last year’s US Tour was a fantastic experience, and a memorable trip for all the players and staff," said Wrexham manager Phil Parkinson. "After another successful campaign, we’re delighted to be heading to the West Coast again this summer, and we’re also looking forward to venturing up to Vancouver and spreading the Club’s footprint into Canada. It will be a great chance to meet new supporters, while also building for the 2024/25 League One season."

This summer also presents the Wrexham women's team to enjoy a high-profile American showcase. The Lady Dragons will play both SoCal FC and Tigres Femenil U19 at UCLA's Drake Stadium before playing a Portland Thorns Academy squad in Rose City. The revitalization of Wrexham's women's program was a priority for McElhenny and Reynolds, earning promotion to the top-flight of Welsh football and setting the nation's all-time domestic football attendance record at nearly 10,000.

"Our focus on elevating women's sports makes Ally the perfect teammate to bring Wrexham AFC Women to the U.S. for the first time," said Andrea Brimmer, chief Marketing and Public Relations officer, Ally. "The Wrex Coast Tour gives them the stage they have rightfully earned by capturing hearts with their stories and brilliant play."

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Romelu Lukaku return claims amid Joshua Zirkzee demands
body: Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag is keen for additions to his squad this summer with the Red Devils continuing to be linked with a host of names including Romelu Lukaku and Joshua Zirkzee
Manchester United have a number of positions that they want to improve ahead of next season.
Erik ten Hag ’s side need some major additions if they are to improve on last season’s miserable showing. The Red Devils slumped to eighth in the Premier League.
United’s major problems appeared to come from their lack of goalscoring threat. And fortunately, Ten Hag wants to add a new striker to his ranks.
A number of strikers have been linked with a move to Old Trafford. Take a look at all of the latest Red Devils transfer rumours from over the past 24 hours:

Manchester United are reportedly eyeing a return for former striker Romelu Lukaku should they fail to sign Joshua Zirkzee. The Dutchman has been installed as the Red Devils’ preferred candidate for a striker signing. But a deal is difficult. The Red Devils face competition from Arsenal and AC Milan for Zirkzee.
And should they fail to sign him, they could turn to a familiar face. According to CalcioMercato, Lukaku has been earmarked for a return.
The Belgian is fresh off the back of a loan spell with Roma but is still contracted to Chelsea. Lukaku scored 42 goals in 96 appearances for the Red Devils during his first spell at Old Trafford.

While the Red Devils are eyeing both Zirkzee and Lukaku, the same could be said of AC Milan. Intriguingly, Hernan Crespo has demanded the Italian giants move for the latter instead - which could leave the door open for Man United to swoop for Zirkzee.

Speaking to Gazzetta dello Sport, the former striker said: “Zirkzee had an excellent season with Bologna, scoring 11 goals. Lukaku wasn’t brilliant last season, but if he has the right motivation and if he’s well prepared from a physical point of view, he can be a guarantee.

“Zirkzee is young, how could he cope with the impact at San Siro? Believe me, someone who has experienced that emotion will tell you: playing in that stadium is not like playing anywhere else. Lukaku is used to the big stage. For today’s Milan, Lukaku is more suitable.”

But they need to wait before a move is formalised. Gutierrez is currently with Girona - and helped the club reach the Champions League last season.
Real Madrid retain a £6.7million buy-back clause. They are apparently set to activate that before selling Gutierrez straight on to the Red Devils.

headline: How Manchester United football structure will work and who does what after latest appointment
body: Ineos have added another appointment to their football structure at Man Utd with former Chelsea man Christopher Vivell coming in.

Manchester United's new director of global talent will be tasked with finding players to fit into Erik ten Hag's first-team squad and who are capable of playing in the style the Dutchman is set to implement in his third season in charge.

Vivell started work in the short-term role on Thursday but his stay at Old Trafford could yet be made permanent. He will report to sporting director Dan Ashworth, who started at the club earlier this week.
The 37-year-old spent seven years working in recruitment roles and as a technical director for the Red Bull network of clubs, before a short stint as technical director at Chelsea.

Vivell made his name in recruitment at RB Salzburg and RB Leipzig and he will lend that expertise in spotting talent from around the world to United, with the chief aim of recommending players capable of slotting into the first-team squad.

He will also play a role in identifying younger players for United and will draw up a development pathway for any emerging talent, showing them a route to the first-team squad and how they would fit in stylistically.

Vivell will report directly to Ashworth, who will lead all football departments for the men, women and academy, and will oversee technical, performance and operational areas. Ashworth will report to chief executive Omar Berrada once he starts next Saturday.
Technical director Jason Wilcox will also report to Ashworth. He joined the club from Southampton in April and part of his responsibility will be to lead on all first-team recruitment.
Wilcox is also tasked with working with Erik ten Hag and the first-team coaches on implementing a clear style of play, or a 'game model' as Wilcox has termed it.
The former Manchester City academy director will work to reproduce that game model into a clear methodology that can be implemented across the men's first team and throughout the academy.

headline: Erik ten Hag's two-word Manchester United statement offers hope for the future
body: After three weeks of talks Man Utd decided to trigger the extension in Erik ten Hag's contract but the Dutchman insists there is a working relationship with Ineos.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

It's fair to say that when Ineos and Erik ten Hag opened talks over a new contract for the Manchester United boss, this wasn't the outcome that was initially envisioned. If the plan had always been to simply take the option in the Dutchman's contract, they would have done so while they sat around the sun loungers in Ibiza.

What happened between now and then to lead us to this position is unclear. What is clear is that United wanted to sell this as a contract being extended. Perhaps it's semantics, but in reality, what has happened is a formality that was available to them the moment Ten Hag signed his first contract in 2022.
He remains on the same financial package he was already on, maintains his transfer veto and is still listed as the club's manager. Nothing has really changed at all.

This decision does at least provide some clarity. There would have been a desire on all sides to have an agreement before pre-season training on Monday and if the outcome was only ever leading to the one-year extension being activated, then that is clearly the best option.

From what both camps had indicated after their Ibiza summit on June 11, this wasn't the expected outcome. It still provides clarity, however. Ten Hag now has two years left on his deal and he has had at least a show of some support from Ineos, even if it is not the kind of deal he might have expected.

Ten Hag and new sporting director Dan Ashworth did at least sing from the same hymn sheet during their comments on the extension. In particular, Ten Hag mixed his pride at two trophies in two seasons with an acceptance that things can get better. He also offered encouraging words about the new structure he is working under at United.
"In my discussions with the club, we have found complete unity in our vision for reaching those goals, and we are all strongly committed to making that journey together," he said.

'Complete unity,' that has to be taken as a positive. Ten Hag's powerbase has diminished at Old Trafford and it could shrink further if he loses long-term assistant Mitchell van der Gaag, who could seek a managerial role of his own if Ruud van Nistelrooy and Rene Hake are appointed.

The key to Ten Hag proving he is worthy of more than just a one-year option on his contract will be how his relationships with the key figures appointed by Ineos develop. He has already had plenty of discussion time with the company's head of sport Sir Dave Brailsford and has been working closely with technical director Jason Wilcox.

Now Ten Hag has to co-exist with the most powerful figure in the football structure, the recently-appointed Ashworth who started work this week, as well as forging a relationship with chief executive Omar Berrada, who starts a week on Saturday. The rest of July and August and the success or otherwise of the transfer window will be the first step on the road to making sure that the unity on show at the moment survives into the season.

Then it is down to Ten Hag to deliver. If he gets the signings he wants this summer, results must follow. Ashworth's comment about needing more consistency highlighted the club's standing. Days like the FA Cup final indicated the potential within United with Ten Hag in charge.
Now, more days like that must follow. If they do then the key figures at United will be signing from the same hymn sheet for a little longer yet.

headline: 5 issues in Erik ten Hag's in-tray that he must fix immediately after new Man United deal
body: Erik ten Hag has signed a new contract at Manchester United until 2026 and the Dutchman has plenty of work to do to ensure his side have a better season than they did last time out

Erik ten Hag has penned a new contract with Manchester United, which means he can start addressing the club's many problems.

Following the club's worst Premier League season in history, Ten Hag has a monumental task ahead of him to pull United out of the slump they've been mired in over the past year. His team finished a staggering 31 points behind champions Manchester City in eighth place and suffered 19 defeats across all competitions.

The victory in last month's FA Cup final, along with the performance that accompanied it, provided a much-needed lift after nine months of relentless negativity. Though it wasn't sufficient enough to erase the memory of their disastrous season.

As such, the coming months could prove pivotal for the Dutch manager. With this in mind, here are five key issues Ten Hag must address promptly following his contract extension at Old Trafford to ensure smooth sailing next season.

First and foremost, Ten Hag must tackle the elephant in the room: Sir Jim Ratcliffe isn't exactly his biggest fan. Almost immediately after the billionaire's minority stake in the club was confirmed earlier this year, rumours began circulating that he was considering potential replacements for the Dutchman.

Following the end of the season, the club spent a few weeks in discussions with other managers, including ex-Chelsea boss Thomas Tuchel, before ultimately deciding to stick with the former Ajax boss. So brazenly speaking to other coaches suggests that Ten Hag could be on thin ice should United hit another rough patch, so he needs to move quickly to prove his worth to Ratcliffe.

There are numerous gaps in United's squad that need addressing, particularly in defence and midfield. The club has been actively seeking a new centre-back, with Matthijs de Ligt, Jarrad Branthwaite and Marc Guehi all being considered, and they are also strongly linked with PSG midfielder Manuel Ugarte.
Securing two or three top-quality players this summer could make the difference between a strong start to the season and a lacklustre one, so prioritising these transfers is crucial for Ten Hag.
Likewise, resolving the futures of players such as Jadon Sancho, Casemiro and Harry Maguire needs to be done promptly, as all three are rumoured to be facing the exit.

Sancho's issues with Ten Hag are well known, and failing to either offload or reconcile with the Englishman could lead to serious problems. Meanwhile, if United sign new players in their positions, high earners Casemiro and Maguire will need to be moved on.

Despite the FA Cup victory, the atmosphere at Old Trafford is currently quite bleak. Confidence seems to be at an all-time low, not just among the players but also the fans, and it's a problem Ten Hag needs to tackle swiftly.

To exorcise the demons of the previous season will require significant effort, including a robust and positive pre-season as well as strategic signings and departures. This could potentially reinvigorate the team and restore some faith.
If Ten Hag can get the squad performing at their peak, he'll quickly regain the support of the fans and crucially, of Ratcliffe.
Marcus Rashford's performance last season was worrisome. The 26-year-old only managed to score just eight goals in all competitions, with a mere two before Christmas.

Considering he scored 30 goals the previous season, it's clear how important it is to bring out his best and how much United's season could depend on which version of Rashford shows up for the campaign next month. If Ten Hag can transform Rashford from a purple patch player into a consistently decisive one he'll be on easy street - and it'll take some pressure off Rasmus Hojlund too!

United were hit with 60 different injuries last season, with key players such as Varane, Hojlund, Lisandro Martinez, Mason Mount, Christian Eriksen, Luke Shaw and Casemiro sidelined for extended periods. This disrupted the team's rhythm significantly and Ten Hag must do everything in his power to avoid a repeat.

Whether that involves adjusting training methods, relying more heavily on the medical team, or allowing for longer recovery times - reportedly an issue last season - it's something Ten Hag should seriously consider.

Romelu Lukaku to Manchester United? Surely not again. Well, rumours circulated earlier this week suggesting that the Red Devils are considering a shock move for the Chelsea forward as a potential alternative to Joshua Zirkzee.

According to Calciomercato, United would consider a surprise switch to bring Lukaku back to Old Trafford this summer if they cannot get a deal for Zirkzee completed. United are keen to add another centre forward to their squad and have identified Zirkzee, who scored 12 goals in 37 matches for Bologna last season, as a priority target. The 23-year-old has a £34million release clause in his contract.

United are pushing to try and get a deal done for the Netherlands international, with Arsenal, AC Milan, and Juventus among his other potential suitors. However, should United fail to sign Zirkzee, then Lukaku has reportedly emerged as another possible striker target - five years since leaving the club. The 31-year-old spent two years at United, scoring 42 goals in 96 matches.

Lukaku is currently employed by Chelsea but hasn't played a single minute for the Blues since 2022, having spent the last two years on loan at Inter Milan and Roma. He made the £97.5m switch to Stamford Bridge in August 2021 but failed to impress in his debut season, despite scoring 15 goals in 44 matches.

A fractured relationship with boss Thomas Tuchel saw Lukaku move to Inter on loan in June 2022. He scored 14 times in 37 appearances while back at the San Siro before signing for Jose Mourinho's Roma last summer, again in a season-long loan deal. Lukaku excelled at the I Giallorossi, hitting 21 goals in 47 games. That return has seen Lukaku gain significant interest, with Chelsea prepared to sell him this summer.

If reports are true, United could be in line to bring back the Belgium international to the club. However, Erik ten Hag should simply avoid going back to sign Lukaku. At 31, he doesn't have age on his side anymore and may only have a couple of years left in him at the very top level.

As a short-term option, I could see why United might look at Lukaku, but they should be looking at the long-term and trying to recruit someone younger who has more potential. Bringing in Rasmus Hojlund, who was 20 at the time, felt like the right type of signing for United. And having another youthful prospect to battle alongside him for the first-choice striker berth could work wonders.

Lukaku would not be happy playing second fiddle or sitting on the bench for a vast majority of the season if he were to join United and be behind Hojlund, who is clearly going to be first-choice. Manchester United have been told that centre-back Matthijs de Ligt will only let them negotiate with him this summer as he plans an exit from Bayern Munich.

The Dutch international has fallen down the pecking order at the Allianz Arena, with Bayern having recently hired Vincent Kompany to replace Thomas Tuchel, who only started De Ligt 16 times in the Bundesliga last season. Despite the managerial change, it seems clear that De Ligt sees United as his only option to secure regular minutes.

United's defensive line is an area in desperate need of an upgrade given the number of injuries they suffered in that area last season, as well as the departure of Raphael Varane, who ended his three-year stint at Old Trafford in May following the expiration of his contract.

headline: 'It needs to be addressed' – Sir Alex Ferguson’s ex-assistant makes Ronaldo thoughts clear
body: Former Manchester United coach Rene Meulensteen has given a bleak assessment of Cristiano Ronaldo's performances for Portugal at Euro 2024

Rene Meulensteen has delivered a blunt assessment of Cristiano Ronaldo's performances for Portugal in Euro 2024.

Meulensteen, an ex-Manchester United first-team coach and confidant to Sir Alex Ferguson, who worked with Ronaldo at Old Trafford, gave his thoughts during an appearance on talkSPORT. The Dutchman expressed concern over Ronaldo's free-kick record and suggested that Portugal manager Roberto Martinez needs to tackle the issue.

He also pointed out that the game seems to be slipping away from the veteran footballer, reports the Mirror. During the interview, talkSPORT co-host Alex Crooks questioned Meulensteen about Ronaldo's impact on the national team:
Crook asked: "Are they a better team without him in it, Portugal? He takes every free kick, blazes every free kick into the stands."
Meulensteen acknowledged the need for a change, saying: "Yeah well, that to me is something I think that needs to be addressed because the stats don't help."

Meulensteen also touched upon Ronaldo's emotional reaction during the round of 16 match against Slovenia, where he was visibly upset after his penalty was saved by Jan Oblak but later scored in the shoot-out.

Reflecting on the situation, Meulensteen remarked: "Well, it's all about perception isn't it? First of all, I thought when that penalty shoot-out came about, I thought this is going to be interesting because he's only going to take one or another penalty he's either the first one or number five, the last one.

"And I was pleasantly surprised for him to step up and take the first one because he knew, 'I need to take the responsibility, I need to put this right to get us off of the wrong foot'. So that to me was a good sign of character."

Meulensteen added: "What happened after the game showed his determination and his desire to win things and to do well that is so strong. He's got the highest expectations of himself and everybody around him. He expects the highest standards of himself and everybody else, and if he doesn't meet those standards - which he didn't - then obviously you get that reaction from him."
Meulensteen also highlighted that Ronaldo needs to justify any claim to taking free-kicks for Portugal by improving his success rate.

He explained: "The only way to justify it [taking free kicks] is to put one in the top corner and that is obviously what he's got in his mind but the stats don't back that up and the thing is, you know with every team normally, you've got a clear plan with everything in terms of the corners, who takes them and the free kicks and this and that and the other.
"He sees them [free kicks] as an opportunity but it's not working and I think it's the manager's job to address that."

Jim White, formerly of Sky Sports Transfer Deadline Day, put the question to Meulensteen regarding whether he'd include Ronaldo in Portugal's starting line-up for their upcoming match against France on Friday night. White queried: "If you were Martinez, I'm going to do it, I'm going to put you in that spot, would you play him in this game against the French on Friday, would you start him?"
Meulensteen replied: "Yeah, I would start him, yeah I would."

White then asked if Meulensteen would give any specific pre-match instructions, to which Meulensteen replied: "I would probably have a clear conversation with him then with the leadership group and also in the tactical way that we, if we think we're going to beat France then I expect something different from you, from you, from you and from you."
He added: "And the only way we can do that is if we pull together and let everybody play to their strength, so therefore this is how we're going to do it."

headline: Man United careful buying from Bayern Munich after what happened in two transfer windows
body: Only three players have moved between Bayern Munich and Man United, with all three heading in the direction of Manchester.

The blond-haired Bayern Munich defender Manchester United should be making a beeline for is Joshua Kimmich, not Matthijs de Ligt.

United will have glanced at Kimmich. He is out of contract at Bayern next year and the noise coming out of Bavaria suggests he is available. Perhaps Kimmich is bound for Barcelona, where his former coach Hansi Flick has replaced Xavi.

Before Sir Jim Ratcliffe surfaced in the Old Trafford directors' box, United were tracking prospective targets due to have a year left on their contract this summer. Ratcliffe has namechecked the Transfermarkt website and Kimmich is listed as the 11th most-expensive player out of contract next year.

Transfermarkt's numbers are as infamous as they are inexplicable. Scott McTominay, the subject of a rejected £30m offer by West Ham last year before he had a career-best season, is listed at £27m. De Ligt, a substitute for club and country, is valued at €65m when United have been quoted €15m less. Kimmich is rated at €50m.
EXCLUSIVE: United set to sign Slovakia winger
As a final fee, that would be reasonable for a 29-year-old with plenty of mileage left. Kimmich is a better right back than the two at United and an upgrade on their senior midfielders.

He is nine years Kobbie Mainoo's senior and would be a worthy partner. Stolen from RB Leipzig for €7m when he was only 20 in 2015, Kimmich has a pedigree befitting a Bayern and Germany stalwart: enough medals to warrant an extension for a trophy room and ten appearances short of becoming a centurion for Die Mannschaft.

United and Bayern share a close bond through the Munich air disaster and Bayern delegates continue to visit the Manchesterplatz site on February 6. The clubs have arranged three legends matches in the past decade and Sir Alex Ferguson has rhapsodized about Bayern's identity and structure.
There have been only three player trades between the clubs and they have all gone to United: Owen Hargreaves and Bastian Schweinsteiger permanently, and Marcel Sabitzer on loan.
Uli Hoeness accused Hargreaves of "prostituting" himself amid United's efforts to sign him in 2006. The move eventually went through the next summer.

Louis van Gaal reunited with Schweinsteiger but also wanted Robert Lewandowski and Thomas Muller. Ed Woodward was so bruised by the failure of Schweinsteiger in 2015 he gave Jerome Boateng short shrift three years later.

Amid the scramble for a centre back in the final week of that fraught summer transfer window, Boateng was suggested as a possibility, only civil war was brewing at United. They was no director of communications, Woodward seemed to be avoiding Jose Mourinho and messages were mixed. Anthony Martial was not for sale in Woodward's eyes but he was in Mourinho's.

Boateng was swiftly discounted by Woodward, who cited United's track record of signing crocks from Bayern. Boateng had missed 23 of Bayern's games the previous season and that was a stark enough red flag for Woodward to veto a move. Boateng would go on to start in Bayern's victorious Champions League final in 2020.

The age profile of United's targets this summer has been in the early 20s. United idealistically targeted players of a similar age in the 2019 summer window, ended it two targets short, suffered key injuries to Luke Shaw, Anthony Martial and Paul Pogba in August and were suddenly exposed.

In the listless 1-0 loss at Newcastle in early October, three starters were aged 21, one was 20 and another 22, while four teenagers were on the bench. Without the mid-season arrival of the 25-year-old Bruno Fernandes, United were destined to finish outside of the top four.

United have two poster boys in Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho, who turned 20 on Monday, while there is potential in the callow Rasmus Hojlund. The man United want to support Hojlund - Joshua Zirkzee - is another early-20s striker in Italy with a modest goalscoring record.

Mainoo and Garnacho, the scorers in the FA Cup final, kept the red flag flying high in a draining season. Their exceptional starts in the first team are all the more laudable as they entered a dressing room devoid of an established leadership group. Cristiano Ronaldo was surrounded by serial winners Gary Neville, Paul Scholes, Roy Keane and Ryan Giggs in 2003. Ruud van Nistelrooy merits mention in the same breath.

Ronaldo, Casemiro and Raphael Varane shared the same four walls for a few months in 2022 but two have gone and the other could be going. In the unlikely event Fernandes were to go, there is not an obvious replacement to assume the captaincy as there was when Harry Maguire was stripped of it last year.

Kimmich has captained Bayern and Germany countless times. He is a year younger than Schweinsteiger when he became United's "first Kraut" (his words) but Schweinsteiger, already greying, looked older and the wear and tear started to take its toll. He did not start another Premier League game in his last 14 months at United.
Kimmich's longest lay-off was 14 games and that was before he joined Bayern. He has missed a mere 34 Bayern matches in nine seasons.
De Ligt has missed as many in just over a third of that time.

headline: Manchester United have done the right thing with Erik ten Hag's contract
body: Ineos were caught between a rock and a hard place after they decided to keep a manager they were planning on sacking.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
An agent who has dealt with Manchester United messaged earlier this week: "Everything must change for everything to remain the same."
Erik ten Hag's situation remains unchanged. He is on the same contract he signed to take over as United manager in April 2022.

Initially, United were unable to confirm whether they had triggered the one-year extension in Ten Hag's contract or just extended his contract. Eventually, a source clarified the one-year option had been exercised.
That is a crucial difference. Whatever Ten Hag's requests or demands under the new co-owner, they are not contractual.

When Ten Hag spoke to Dutch broadcaster NOS last month, he said: "We had a good talk and various topics were discussed and the conclusion was that we will continue with each other but also the conclusion is that we are going to sit down to renew the contract."
EXCLUSIVE: United set to sign Slovakia winger
The interviewer replied: "Okay, so the air is cleared and you go because you have another year's contract and you're going to renew now?"
"Well of course, we absolutely have to come to some sort of agreement," Ten Hag replied. An agreement was technically unnecessary.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe and his Ineos cohorts were caught between a rock and a hard place. Offer Ten Hag a longer contract and they appear weak, having intended to sack him until the FA Cup final. Take up the one-year option and it is hardly a ringing endorsement.
But it is also sensible. Jose Mourinho and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer were sacked in the same year they signed completely new contracts. United have moved on from Ed Woodward's gullible ways.

It still feels like an uneasy alliance and effectively extends Ten Hag's trial period. United will have their three "pillars" - Dan Ashworth, Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox - in place to judge him next season.
Ashworth said: "With two trophies in the past two seasons, Erik has reinforced his record as one of the most consistently successful coaches in European football.
"While the club’s review of last season highlighted areas for improvement, it also reached a clear conclusion that Erik was the best partner for us to work with in driving up standards and outcomes.

"This group of players and staff have already shown they are capable of competing and winning at the top level; now we need to do it more consistently. With our strengthened football leadership team now in place, we are looking forward to working hand-in-hand with Erik to achieve our shared ambitions for this football club."

That struck a diplomatic but defiant tone. United have a nucleus to build a new squad around, Ten Hag's standout victories have come against the elite (Liverpool in August 2022, Barcelona in February 2023 and City in May 2024), the academy secured a triple-crown last term and Ten Hag is a great champion of United's youth identity.

United have implemented their new structure quickly and the aforementioned trio are duty bound to support the manager who has chiselled two years onto an honours board that was unchanged for nearly six years. United now have to be proactive with signings and sales.

Ten Hag will soon be supported by compatriots on the coaching staff in Ruud van Nistelrooy and Rene Hake. Ten Hag is a stickler for the familiar and/or the Dutch, though the seniority of the support raises questions.

The seasons become more pivotal at United and Ten Hag has 11 months to earn improved terms. Take United back into the Champions League, get his hands on more silverware and his hand will be strengthened.
Then things may change.

headline: Man United already know Christopher Vivell transfer demand after £300m blockbuster spend
body: Manchester United transfer news as new director eyed less than two years after being appointed by Chelsea.

A club massively underperforming both on and off the pitch, in need of more transfer efficiency, recently with fresh outside investment and a new look sporting structure being hastily put in place after years of neglect.

There are plenty of parallels between Chelsea's December 2022 appointment of Christopher Vivell and the circumstances in which Manchester United are looking at bringing him into. Right the way down to the period of time that the new ownership groups had been in charge, the similarities are there.

Unlike many of these deals, though, it is not because of the work Vivell did at Stamford Bridge that he is being targeted by United as a short-term director. According to The Athletic, the German is being courted as a possible summer arrival to help oversee the summer window.

It comes at the same time that Dan Ashworth has finally seen his move to Old Trafford confirmed. Chief executive Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox are the other names in the backroom team that Sir Jim Ratcliffe and his Ineos group are putting in place.
But Vivell is not, it appears, part of the long-term plans for the furniture at United. That doesn't mean he can't have an impact.

Vivell's track record to date is impressive. He headed the work in scouting, coordination, and squad planning in the much revered Red Bull success stories Salzburg and Leipzig. Before that he impressed in roles at Hoffenheim, where he worked with Julian Nagelsmann. And then there's his brief period at Chelsea.

The only full transfer window he was involved at in London was mixed, to say the least. For Malo Gusto there is Mykhailo Mudryk. If Benoit Badaishile is seen as a good piece of business, then Noni Madueke splits opinion. It may have only been on paper but Vivell was theoretically one of the leading parts of the team at Chelsea when they went deep into deadline day in January 2023 to break the British transfer record for Enzo Fernandez.

That came just six months after he had moved to Benfica for ten times less. He is yet to show why that level of outlay was spent. Christopher Nkunku is a fine player but by the time Vivell was in charge it was already largely in place for him to join Chelsea. There was £300million spent that winter with Vivell involved.

One window later and he was on gardening leave. Chelsea had made Paul Winstanley and Lawrence Stewart - both with impressive CVs but in differing circumstances - the real heads for their new model. Vivell was out before he even settled.

There have been suggestions that he was disenfranchised with the way the structure was working. Too many cooks spoil the broth, or so they say. It was a concern at the time when Chelsea hired four new directors into a team, each with their own targets and ideas.

Vivell was never the key man at Chelsea. He was perhaps the most noteworthy but was not the director who became a household name or made the biggest impact. Instead, it was co-owner Behdad Eghbali and Winstanley who went on to run the roost.
United certainly won't be able to say that they don't know how Vivell likes to work. And frankly, why wouldn't they like what he has to offer?

Vivell boasts a strong array of players signed at Leipzig and Salzburg. Dominik Szoboszlai, Erling Haaland, and Benjamin Sesko are just a few. Josko Gvardiol, Timo Werner, and Mohamed Simakan are others.

Nagelsmann was allowed to thrive as a head coach within the environment that he helped to create.

This is all idyllic for United. How much of this can Vivell help to implement in a matter of months? It's hard to know. Advisors, as he may well effectively be, are extremely useful though, and with other new important figures waiting to get themselves going at Carrington, or else with plans to look beyond the first realistic chance for Ratcliffe and co to get down to action, Vivell could be a smart appointment himself.

The big question for United, and for Vivell, is just what sort of control he will be given. When it comes to building squads for a defined style of play he is one of the most established in the world, but as Chelsea witnessed in a fashion not too far from United's current situation, leaving the waters muddy will benefit nobody.

headline: Matthijs de Ligt would be a transfer nine years in the making at Manchester United
body: Man United would be banking on a player's form five years ago rather than in the last five years if they sign Matthijs de Ligt.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

There is a new technical director, an inaugural sporting director and another sporting director on the board who is assisted by a sport project manager. Yet Manchester United continue to target players who are Dutch, or have played for Ajax, or for the manager.

Matthijs de Ligt ticks all three boxes. Five years ago, the 19-year-old De Ligt was the nascent centre back in world football after Ajax's domestic double and captivating run to the Champions League semi-final.

United did not discourage their interest in De Ligt but he was never a realistic target as they were in the Europa League. United are back in the Europa next season. That De Ligt is receptive to joining Europa United tells you all you need to know about his decline.
De Ligt danced to the tune of his agent, the late Mino Raiola, and joined Juventus in 2019. That never seemed like a snug fit and he was sold to Bayern Munich after three years.

At Bayern last season, De Ligt started a paltry 23 games. He has not had a kick at the European Championship in an admittedly impressive Dutch defence. De Ligt played one minute at the 2022 World Cup.
United sounded out Thomas Tuchel, De Ligt's manager last season, only last month. Had they replaced Erik ten Hag with Tuchel they would not be starying anywhere near De Ligt.

United have a long history with De Ligt. He was 11 when he started for Ajax's under 13s against United in the warm-up act to Edwin van der Sar's testimonial at the Amsterdam Arena back in 2011. De Ligt was the daring yet dithering defender pickpocketed to set a United whippersnapper on his way to get the equalising goal. The whippersnapper was Callum Gribbin.

Four years before De Ligt transferred to Juventus for £68m, he was recommended by the United head of youth recruitment Derek Langley. United compiled innumerable scouting reports but the hierarchy vetoed a move.
In a heated exchange with Ed Woodward, Langley questioned the competency of those running the club. Seven months later, Langley was gone.

United's emotionally-charged Europa League final triumph over Ajax in 2017 was such an uncompetitive contest as they neutered De Ligt. United players were instructed to press De Ligt, identified as a dexterous distributor, but stand off his partner at centre back, Davinson Sanchez, whenever he had the ball. The more limited Sanchez hoiked the ball into United territory, where Marouane Fellaini was head and shoulders above all in the aerial duels.

When Jose Mourinho took over at Tottenham, he could not resist reminding Sanchez of the occasion. Mourinho asked Sanchez if he had "balls" as Ajax "s**t themselves" in the final. "I won the game minute one," Mourinho bragged.

Before De Ligt's breakthrough performances in the Champions League, Mourinho suggested him as a possible reinforcement. Marcel Bout, the head of global scouting and only surviving member of Louis van Gaal's staff, expressed concerns about De Ligt's physique on account of his reputedly rotund father.

All three of Ten Hag's blond bombshells at Ajax have endured difficulties away from the Amster. De Ligt has become a substitute for club and country, Barcelona accepted an offer from United for Frenkie de Jong two years ago and Donny van de Beek will be released next year if he is not sold this year.

Ten Hag backs himself to revive De Ligt but his prospective signing would be based on form five years ago rather than form in the last five years. De Ligt has not been a success in Serie A or the Bundesliga, yet is deemed suitable for the more taxing Premier League at the most scrutinised sporting institution on the planet.

Compatriots Virgil van Dijk, Nathan Ake and Micky van de Ven are among the outstanding defenders in England. Van Dijk moved to Britain when he was 21 and Ake joined Chelsea's academy at the age of 16. Van de Ven was a stellar piece of business by Tottenham last year.

De Ligt is still only 24 and far from a write-off. He offers longevity, is familiar with the manager's methods and has good pedigree at club and international level. De Ligt has competed in more Champions League semi-finals than United have in 15 years and his attributes represent an upgrade on the potentially outgoing Victor Lindelof, if not Raphael Varane.

Perhaps it is an unfortunate coincidence Juventus and Bayern's dominance eroded shortly after they signed De Ligt. Juve have not won the Scudetto since De Ligt's first season and Bayern's Bundesliga hegemony ended in his second.

And maybe it is rotten luck De Ligt was red-carded in the Netherlands' round-of-16 elimination by the Czech Republic at Euro 2020 before they reached successive quarter-finals with him on the bench in Germany and Qatar.

There are five former Ajax players in the current United squad and four arrived under Ten Hag. Tyrell Malacia and Mason Mount played in the Eredivisie while Rasmus Hojlund and Sofyan Amrabat's representation was taken over by Dutchman Kees Vos, Ten Hag's agent, before their transfers.

Louis van Gaal's rebranding of Barcelona in the Nineties was so Dutchcentric the away kit should have been turned orange. Van Gaal brought in Ruud Hesp, Frank and Ronald de Boer, Michael Reiziger, Phillip Cocu, Winston Bogarde, Patrick Kluivert and Boudewijn Zenden within a three-year period. Barca have not bought that many Dutchmen in the 24 years since Van Gaal offered his amigos de la prensa their congratulations on sacking him.
De Ligt did not get onto the pitch against United in the Allianz Arena last year until full-time when he offered Andre Onana a sympathetic embrace. He was injured for the return match in Manchester.
United, eighth and almost as close to champions Manchester City as relegated Luton Town points-wise, and De Ligt could go hand in glove. They are two fading forces with points to prove.
Langley also endorsed a move for a teenage De Jong. Ten Hag might welcome his return at United.

body: Manchester United are interested in Matthijs de Ligt, but thousands of fans do not want the Netherlands international to move to Old Trafford this summer.

Manchester United's proposed move for Matthijs de Ligt has been hit with controversy after more than 7,000 fans signed a petition against the transfer.

The change.org petition, started by Bayern Munich supporters, started on June 11 but surpassed 7,000 signatures on Tuesday, with another 350 people adding their names during the day. That surge comes amid interest from Manchester United in the Netherlands international.

The club are said to have made contact with Bayern - who reportedly have a £42.5million asking price - and the player. But the Bavarian club being willing to part with the player this summer has not gone down well in Munich among the fanbase, particularly online.

"We all want Matthijs de Ligt to stay at FC Bayern Munich," a section titled 'Why this petition matters' reads. "He has proven that he‘s a world class defender, probably the best in our squad. There is a reason why he was elected as our best player in the 2022/23 season.

"Furthermore he is only 24 years old and has a bright future ahead, which he is going to use to fulfil his huge potential. Despite his young age, Mattha is already very mature and has a great mentality which will definitely make him a leading figure in defence and probably a competitor for captaincy in some years. His ability to speak English, German and Dutch fluently would help him a lot for that. With 19 years he already brought Ajax Amsterdam to the UCL semi-finals as captain.
"Selling Matthijs de Ligt would be an absolutely horrible decision and we would definitely regret it. That‘s why we use our voice to call attention that we will NOT make this mistake!"

De Ligt addressed his future last month before the European Championship began and days after the petition started. "I've already said this is not the time for me to think about it," De Ligt said during a press conference.

"We're playing at the Euros now, and that's very important for me and the national team. That's why I can't say now what I think about this situation. But what I can say is that I've now played my second season at Bayern - I'm very happy. For now, I'm focused on the Euros, and then we'll see what happens."

Manchester United are hopeful of signing Bayern Munich defender Matthijs de Ligt.
Bayern are prepared to sell De Ligt, 24, after only two years and he is valued at around £42million.

United want to sign two centre backs and have already had a bid of £35m rising to £43m rejected for Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite. Everton value Branthwaite at between £70m-£80m and United are operating on a budget of tens of millions, excluding funds from sales.

United have released Raphael Varane and want to sell fellow centre half Victor Lindelof as he is out of contract next year. United have an existing relationship with De Ligt's agent, Rafaela Pimenta, who has visited the club's training complex over the last year.

De Ligt played under United manager Erik ten Hag at Ajax before he joined Juventus in a £68m deal in 2019. The defender remains a big fan of his former manager and after Ten Hag had been confirmed as Manchester United's new manager, De Ligt tipped him to be a success, saying: "He is someone who loves his job and he loves to work. He wants to do everything to make his team play better.
"He's really into the details. This makes him a really good trainer who improves players. He has a lot of qualities to succeed and we will have to see how he goes.”
There are currently five former Ajax players in the United squad and four arrived after Ten Hag's appointment in May 2022.
United scouted De Ligt when he was a teenager at Ajax and their then head of youth recruitment, Derek Langley, later revealed the club vetoed a move for the Dutchman.
De Ligt is in the Netherlands squad at the European Championship but has not played in any of their four matches in Germany.

headline: 'Drastic waste' - Dan Ashworth hint about how Manchester United recruitment will change
body: Man Utd have a new sporting director after Dan Ashworth started work this week and he has already explained his approach to recruitment.

It's all a bit double Dutch for Manchester United so far this summer. Ruud van Nistelrooy and Rene Hake being lined up to join the coaching staff and Matthijs de Ligt and Joshua Zirkzee leading targets to reinforce the two priority areas in Erik ten Hag's first-team squad.

If De Ligt was to join from Bayern Munich and Zirkzee from Bologna it would take the number of players of Dutch origin, or who have played in the Eredivisie, to nine, although that includes Donny van de Beek, who is peripheral to this squad at best. It wouldn't exactly give the impression of United moving away from a transfer strategy dictated by the manager.

That is the situation Sir Jim Ratcliffe was keen to avoid when Ineos got the keys to Old Trafford. Speaking in February, he explained his desire to revamp the football structure at the club and get away from a model that hands so much power to the manager.

"What you need are the foundations to be in a good place for Manchester United to be successful, which means that, from our point of view anyway, you need the right organisational structure," Ratcliffe said.

"Which means not having a coach reporting to the chief executive, for instance, which is what they've got at the moment. You need the right organisation structure and that's not going to be too complicated."

That structure is pretty much in place now. Dan Ashworth leads it as the sporting director, reporting to a chief executive, which for now is Jean-Claude Blanc but will be Omar Berrada from July 13. Below Ashworth is technical director Jason Wilcox, while Christopher Vivell is also set to take up a narrower recruitment role.

With Ashworth having started work after an end to four months of negotiations with Newcastle, United can begin to redraw their structure when it comes to decisions around transfers. The idea will be to give Ten Hag less power than he has had in his first two summer windows.

Under the Glazer regime, with a chief executive focused on commercial success in Richard Arnold and football director John Murtough, Ten Hag guided the decision-making and took on a bigger role when it came to transfers, with United restructuring their scouting and recruitment operation.

There have been hits and misses for Ten Hag in the market, but Ashworh has a reputation for shrewd recruitment and will take on a major role, although as sporting director his job is far more wide-reaching than just transfers. At Brighton, he was technical director and let head of recruitment Paul Winstanley generally guide the way on deals.

Ashworth had his say, however, and in a December 2020 interview with Traning Ground Guru, he explained how a collaborative approach was required, which would still give Ten Hag a say now, even if his power is ever-so-slightly reduced when he signs a new contract.

"If I sign a player that Graham [Potter] doesn’t like or want, it’s a drastic waste of resources. Ultimately, Graham has got to pick 11 players that he thinks will give him the best chance of winning," Ashworth said.
"If he doesn’t rate the attributes in a player that I do, then we are going to invest a transfer fee, salary and agent’s fee for a player that Graham doesn’t rate or want and who is unlikely to play.

"So how do we work here? Well, we agree the areas of the pitch that Graham wants to improve. Our first port of call is 'what have we already got in the system?' There have been times when Graham has said: 'I’d rather work with what we’ve got and make them better than sign a player for the sake of it.'
"But if we haven’t got that position in the U23s or out on loan then we need to go into the market."

Ashworth used the example of Potter wanting a more physical striker and deciding to pursue Danny Welbeck for the role. This summer Ten Hag wants a central defender and a striker as a priority and in the case of De Ligt, there is an obvious connection to use there. He is someone the United manager wants and has a good relationship with.

Ashworth will use his own instincts and contacts as well, however. He did just that when using his time with England and getting to know Tariq Lamptey through the age-group sides. With Reece James blocking his path at Chelsea, he saw the young right-back as a realistic target for Brighton and he has excelled at the Amex.

headline: Some Man United players' futures are becoming more certain as valuation changes - Samuel Luckhurst
body: Man United now have to get into the habit of not letting the manager solely decide players' futures. That forward planning has already started.
